Speaker: Mr TIM WILSON (Goldstein)

name: Bowen, Chris, MP
content: My first political memory—in fact, one of my clearest early memories—was 5 March 1983, the day the Australian people elected the Hawke Labor government. I remember my parents quietly going to Smithfield Public School, where I attended, to cast their votes for Bob Hawke to become Prime Minister—or, more accurately, for my predecessor, Dr Dick Klugman, to be the member for Prospect, as our seat was then called. He was also, ironically enough, my predecessor as shadow health minister. My parents and those millions of Australians who voted to elect Bob Hawke did so with hope, but they could not have envisaged the sea change, the massive revolution, nor the significance of the government that they were electing on 5 March 1983.I didnt see it at the time, but Ive said to people since that if you want to understand the significance, the star that Bob Hawke was in the Australian political landscape, use the wonders of the internet that we now have and YouTube the arrival of Bob Hawke at the National Tally Room down the road here in Canberra; see the aura he had as he and Hazel entered the National Tally Room as the Prime Minister-elect of Australia. He said not a word. He didnt give a speech. He simply walked from one end of the tally room to the other. The impact that had, as the whole country stopped to watch, was enormous. He then undertook a press conference where he thanked the Australian people for their confidence and sent a message to those Australians who did not vote for him. Specifically, he said that he wanted to address the people of Tasmania, who voted very solidly against the Labor Party in that election and elected not one Labor MP, to say that he wanted to lead a government for all Australians—and he certainly did that.He did not see his personal popularity—which, of course, was enormous, with an approval rating of more than 70 per cent—as something to be kept in a cupboard and not put to work for the Australian people. He used that popularity, that political capital, as a bulwark to lead the most reformist government in Australias history, to lead the most significant and sustained period of economic and social change in our country. As has been said, he led a cabinet of talents in a partnership with the Treasurer, Paul Keating, with the most enormous consequences: to modernise the country in a way which had not been attempted or achieved in the past. Much has been made of his reforms—rightly so—of opening the economy, floating the dollar, tearing down the tariff walls, engaging in the great productivity and competitiveness revolution, and his national competition policy. Much has been rightly made of financial deregulation, opening up to foreign banks, freeing the capital markets, liberalising the labour market and ensuring that the economy was modernised and open.He and his government knew that the whole purpose of that was to give something back. They introduced the best healthcare system in the world, Medicare, against ferocious opposition from the medical establishment and from honourable members opposite at that point. They were determined to do so in a way not only to implement but cement the reforms. They were building on the great achievement of Bill Hayden, who should be acknowledged in this debate, the social security minister of the Whitlam government, who had, against the same fierce opposition, introduced Medibank. They took that as a model and introduced Medicare, ensuring that they brought the Australian people with them so that the reform was cemented and so that, despite the political opposition, after successive Labor governments, it could never be undone.Likewise, the beginnings of universal superannuation were completed in the Keating government. It gave Australians the chance of a dignified retirement. Superannuation had been the preserve of a privileged few until the establishment of the Hawke-Keating government and their reforms. They knew that Australians who worked hard all of their lives deserved a dignified retirement. Putting the miracle of compound interest to work for those millions of Australians was something that only a Labor government could achieve. Other honourable members have mentioned the lifting of school retention rates from around 30 per cent to over 80 per cent so that eight in 10 young Australians finished school and had the chance for better and further education. All of these social reforms, investing in the social fabric and providing social conditions and standards, would become the bulwark of our society and could not be resisted.He engaged in economic reforms that were hugely controversial at the time. He introduced the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, which honourable members opposite went to the 1986 election proposing to repeal. He knew that this broadening of the tax base was absolutely essential for the fairness of the tax system as well as for providing the financing of important investments in our social fabric. This was Hawke the reformer and the tackler of tough issues.There was an arrangement between himself and his Treasurer. Hawke could use his very considerable communications skills, matched with those of his Treasurer, to convince the Australian people of the merits of their case. Much of it looks easy in hindsight—inevitable, almost undeniable. But that was not the case. It was hard-fought reform not only in this room but, at some points, in our party. Hawke and Keating famously lost an argument about privatisation at a national conference and delayed the privatisation of Qantas and Australian Airlines by two years, as they continued to argue for these reforms in the party. Of course, they inevitably held the day. This was Hawke the great reformer, for whom our country owes a great deal.Like many honourable members, I came to know Bob Hawke a little later in life. I know that some honourable members know his great partner, and sometimes rival, Paul Keating much more closely. Paul Keating has always recognised the innate power of their partnership: they could only do what they did together, and they could only achieve what they did as a partnership. I last saw Bob at a function for Hannah Beazley, our candidate for the seat of Swan, in Sydney. I was conducting that for her. Being so close to her father, Governor Beazley, he wanted to come to lend his support. I could tell, at that point, that we were nearing the end for Bob Hawke, but we had a good talk on that occasion.He maintained his interest in our movement, our party and the country right until the end. Honourable members will recall his joint stewardship, his joint op-ed in the Fairfax pages in the final stages of the election campaign, endorsing the Labor Party and our economic agenda in the recent election. That was something that Dr Emerson and I had been discussing with Mr Keating, as we talked about whether such an op-ed—it would be the first time they had come together in decades—were possible. They were both keen to do it. Such was Bob Hawkes keen interest. As has been noted, he didnt want to vote postally; he wanted to actually cast a vote on the Saturday for the Labor Party. He wanted to hold on that long. But, alas, it was not to be.Bob Hawke has been rightly noted and lauded by the Prime Minister and others on the other side as one of Australias greatest Prime Ministers, appropriately and rightly so—because he is. He will always be one of the countrys great reformers. He was somebody who dreamed of what could be and somebody who knew it would not be easy but would tackle it nevertheless, because we were not living up to our potential as a country. We were falling short of our massive potential. Bob Hawke could see that in every day of his prime ministership. Bob Hawke was a great Australian in every sense of the word. He was a passionate, patriotic, loving Australian. He loved our country, and he was determined to deliver for it. He was a remarkable man, a remarkable politician. We shall not know his like again. I join with the House in extending my condolences for his loss but my celebration of a life very well lived.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Mr BOWEN (McMahon)

name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
content: I too am privileged to rise to speak on this condolence motion on the death of the Hon. Robert James Lee Hawke, the 23rd Prime Minister of Australia. Indeed, its fitting as Im one of only three members of this chamber—indeed three members of the parliament—who served when Bob Hawke was Prime Minister, the other two being the member for Lingiari, who spoke earlier on this motion, and my good friend the member for Monash. They both served at the time when Bob Hawke was Prime Minister. Indeed, he was Prime Minister when I was first elected to this place in May 1991. It was a position he held until the end of December 1991, when, as others have remarked upon, he was then toppled by Paul Keating and subsequently retired from parliament on 20 February 1992.Bob Hawke was elected Prime Minister in 1983 and became Labors longest-serving Prime Minister, and at that time the nations second longest-serving Prime Minister, a length of time only eclipsed subsequently by John Howard. Bob Hawke was well-known to a generation or two, if not three, of Australians. Prior to coming here, he was a well-known figure in the Australian polity. His time as advocate of the ACTU, his presidency of the ACTU, his presidency of the Australian Labor Party all meant that Australians in every part of this country knew of Bob Hawke and what Bob Hawke stood for.And on coming here and becoming Prime Minister he made an enormous contribution to the welfare and the wellbeing of Australians, as so many other honourable members have noted. I wont repeat all the remarkable achievements of the Hawke-Keating government: the floating of the dollar; the dismantling of the tariffs; reforming of taxation; the introduction of Medicare, which the previous speaker, the member for McMahon, spoke about; and, indeed, the reform of industrial relations. Many of these matters were supported by the then opposition, but it was indeed the leadership of Mr Hawke and his Treasurer at the time, Mr Keating, that led to remarkable changes in the Australian economy and, indeed, in the outlook of this country.In his contribution earlier in the day, the member for Corio referred to the lineage of Jefferson, Lincoln and the Roosevelts in the United States of America. It reminded me of that book by Doris Kearns Goodwin, entitled Team of Rivals, which spoke about Abraham Lincolns amazing presidency and life in the United States. The thing about that was that Lincoln presided over a very talented group of cabinet members, and the same can be said about Bob Hawke. It strikes me that if a Prime Minister, if a leader, doesnt always want to be the smartest person in the room but can recognise and can encourage the contributions, the talents and the expertise of those also sitting around the cabinet table, then the outcome is much greater than any one individual can achieve. Indeed, many have remarked upon how perhaps one of Bob Hawkes greatest contributions to Australian political life was the fact that he was the chairman of a cabinet, a cabinet in which there were many other talented individuals who contributed to the outcome of this country. Indeed, that cabinet was, by modern standards, a relatively small cabinet, but it was a talented cabinet and did great things over that period of time.Successful reform comes from longevity in office, but longevity requires the trust of the Australian people. That trust of the Australian people only comes to leaders who are prepared to listen unceasingly to the Australian people, to know that ultimately we in this place must serve them, that we must meet the challenges of their everyday lives, not just now but the challenges that theyll meet in the future, and have a preparedness to argue for a proposed set of solutions that will address those challenges now and in the future. As other speakers have remarked, it was one of the outstanding achievements of Bob Hawke to unceasingly argue for the proposals that he thought were important to bring about the wellbeing, the welfare and the better economic and social outcomes for the people of Australia. We all stand in his stead in that regard.As I said, I came here in the last months of the Hawke prime ministership. Paul Keating launched his first challenge to Bob Hawke, as I recall, at the end of June in 1991—I think Id been here for a matter of two or three weeks when that happened. Over the course of that period of time when Paul Keating left the frontbench and sat up here on the backbench on this side until the second, successful, challenge occurred in December of that year was a difficult time for Bob Hawke as Prime Minister. Its, sadly, an iron law of Australian politics that two challenges to a Prime Minister will ultimately succeed—one can think of other occasions over succeeding years when thats been the case here in Australia. During that time, Bob Hawke nonetheless continued to argue his case.I remember sitting on the other side of the chamber next to Wilson Tuckey. In one famous encounter between the Speaker and Tuckey—which occurred on a fairly regular occasion at that time—there were no time limits on answers to questions, and I think Bob had been going on for about 14 minutes in the answer to one question. Tuckey famously—some might say infamously—stood up and said to Leo McLeay, who was the Speaker, Mr Speaker, would you put him out of his misery? It was probably unkind in the circumstances, but nonetheless it was a reflection of the willingness of debate which occurred. I say that because in discussions like this sometimes we can be sentimental about the past. Sometimes we can forget that what happens in here is nonetheless a willing debate about a series of issues. But what I think is important about Bob Hawkes legacy is that he saw the common good of this country and what the best outcome was, as far as he saw it, and he was prepared to argue it for this country.Mr Deputy Speaker, each year I travel to your state to watch a certain bike race. When driving over there and back, its become our family practice to stop at the Bordertown Hotel to have lunch on the way back to Melbourne. Every time I pass through Bordertown, Ive thought about Bob Hawke and how this small country town, close to the border of South Australia and Victoria, produced one of our greatest leaders—obviously, Labors greatest Prime Minister—and one of the greatest prime ministers of this country. I was pleased to read therefore that theres been put in place a proposal to purchase the house in which Bob Hawke was born and to turn it into a museum for Bob Hawke—and more broadly for the Labor Party—and the contribution that he made to this country.I think that this is fitting. Far too often we fail in this country to recognise the contributions that leaders on all sides of politics have made to the wellbeing of this country. In Bob Hawke, we had a great leader. Im proud to stand here, as someone who served for a very short period of time in this chamber when he was here, to recognise from the other side of politics that he made a great contribution to this country. I extend my condolences to his family, friends and the wider Labor movement in particular. May he rest in peace.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Mr ANDREWS (Menzies)

name: Clare, Jason, MP
content: When JFK was killed in 1963, Bob Hawke was a young 33-year-old having his first crack at winning a seat here in the federal parliament. He was running then for the seat of Corio—a seat thats now held by my friend Richard Marles. And so the story goes that, apparently, a breathless campaign manager rushed into Bob Hawkes office and told him, Kennedys dead! To which, apparently, Bob Hawke went ashen white and said: What? Graham Kennedy is dead? Thats typical Bob. It tells you everything you need to know about the man. Its all of his innate Australianness captured in one sentence.He loved a drink, and he was good at it; he even held a world record at one point. In 1955, when he was at Oxford University, he drank two and a half pints of beer in 11 seconds. About 50 years later, when he was in his 70s, he was back at Oxford University, then with another Rhodes Scholar—the former President of the United States, Bill Clinton—and he was asked to give it another go. Apparently Bill and Hillary were both yelling out, Go Bob! He got it down then in 20 seconds. He was still doing the same sort of thing at the cricket until a few years ago.Bob Hawke was no ordinary bloke. He was as at home at the hill at the SCG as he was dining with presidents. He was a larrikin statesman. A man with a big brain and an even bigger heart. He wasnt perfect—far from it—but he was honest about his flaws, and people loved him for it. Without question, he was one of the greatest Prime Ministers that this country has ever had.Like so many others here in the parliament, I grew up in what we now call the Hawke era. I grew up watching Bob on TV. He was the man with the funny voice and the big, wavy hair. The man so often with tears in his eyes and the man with the lairy jacket the morning that we won the Americas Cup. But as I grew up, I saw a different Bob Hawke. I realised that he was also the man who gave my mum the green card that she got out whenever we got sick and went to the doctors. He was the man who meant a lot more kids, like me, from working-class suburbs finished high school. In 1983 only three in 10 kids finished high school in Australia. By the time that Bob Hawke was done more than 70 per cent did. I was part of that 70 per cent.Bobs mum, Edith, used to tell him that education was the golden key that unlocked every door and Bob knew that. For a kid like me in the 1980s, the first in my family to finish Year 10—let alone Year 12—I knew that what he did was life changing. Bob was also the man that brought my wifes grandparents from Vietnam to Australia and allowed them to settle here and start a new life in the best country in the world—part of the family reunion program.He didnt just change the lives of individuals; he changed the whole country. We are a very different place today from the country that we were 40 years ago. In 1980, Lee Kuan Yew, former Prime Minister of Singapore, said that Australia was destined to become the poor white trash of Asia. That didnt happen. It didnt happen because of a lot of things that Bob Hawke and Paul Keating did. Things like floating the dollar, cutting tariffs, opening up our economy and enmeshing ourselves with Asia. None of that was easy. It is easy to sit back here today and think that all of that was, but the truth is it only happened because people like Bob, Paul and great union leaders like Bill Kelty fought for it, argued the case for it and persuaded others that we needed it. Not all of it was supported by the coalition. Not all of it was supported by our own side. Bob, Paul and Bill were called sellouts by some.Its not easy to hold your nerve and keep driving forward when people are hurting and industries are buckling under the strain of all of it. We are lucky that they did, because what they did remade Australia—one with more jobs, more businesses and more opportunities than ever existed when I was a boy.Bob also abhorred racism. He mercilessly shamed those who attempted to use it for political advantage here in this place and right across Australia. He helped tear down what Robert Kennedy called the walls of oppression and resistance overseas. The economic sanctions that he convinced other countries to sign up to helped to bring down apartheid in South Africa. When Nelson Mandela visited parliament almost 30 years ago he told Bob that he was here at this time because of him.For a party that I love so much, Bob also taught us how to win and how to govern—something we often need reminding of. As Paul Kelly said in his book The Hawke Ascendancy:The great strength of the Hawke government was the success in capturing that balance between reform and reassurance. Herein lay Hawkes genius. He encamped squarely in the middle of Australian politics and constructed a coalition spanning business on the right and unions on the left. The old Labor Party aligned itself with labour against capital. The Liberal Party was in alliance with capital against Labor. But Hawke sought a compromise which would make the ALP under his leadership the natural majority party.In the last few years, like many other colleagues on this side of the House, I got to spend a bit of time with the man I grew up watching on TV. As others have said, meeting your heroes can be a scary thing, but not Bob. He was always very kind to me. He was always very generous with his time, inviting me back time and again for a cup of coffee. He was always very generous with his advice—always keen to talk about politics, always keen to talk about the party, always keen to talk about the future. He was also very funny. He liked to tell jokes, none of which I can repeat here in the parliament! He always asked about my wife, Louise, and he would often remark that the age gap between me and Louise was the same as between him and Blanche. We also used to talk a bit about death. It struck me that whenever we did, he always seemed very much at peace with it, whenever it was to come. I remember saying to him, Maybe, Bob, thats because you know that even after youre gone much of you will remain. All the things that you did will last many years after youre gone. I think he knew that. I could tell by the look in his eye that he knew that.There are lots of us who yearn for another Bob Hawke. I can understand that. But people like Bob are like Halleys comet—they dont come around that often. I miss him terribly, but I know that instead of mourning him and mourning what weve lost, or hoping somewhat vainly for some kind of political reincarnation some time soon, instead we should take a look around and just be grateful for what hes left us. Hes the green card in our pockets. Hes the superannuation we will retire with. Hes the architect of so much of what is modern day Australia. His invisible fingerprints are all around us, and were a better country for it. As Blanche said in her book about Bob a few years ago, Even though his service to our country is at an end, the long tail of its comet still shines.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Mr CLARE (Blaxland)

name: Chester, Darren, MP
content: It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak on the condolence motion for the Hon. Robert James Lee Hawke. First of all, I want to associate myself with the comments this morning from both the Prime Minister and the member for Grayndler. They were two outstanding tributes to an outstanding Australian. I also congratulate my friend the member for Blaxland for his contribution. Unlike the member for Blaxland, when I grew up Bob Hawke wasnt really regarded very fondly in my house of Country Party voters. They didnt regard him with quite the same reverence that maybe they did in your household but he was respected across the board. Even in the staunch Country Party home of my parents in Sale. They grudgingly acknowledged that Bob got things done.Today, as we rise and make comments, its important that we reflect on a life very well lived, a life of great achievements. Certainly, when it comes to Robert James Lee Hawke, or Bob Hawke, or Hawkie as everyone knew him, it is an extraordinary life that we are reflecting on. He was a giant of politics in his era. I grew up attending high school during that era, and he was a giant of his era in terms of dominating the political stage. Australians loved him for his authenticity and his larrikin spirit. They could all see a bit of themselves in Bob. Its tempting to think of him only in that way, until you start reflecting on the reforming government he led and the achievements, of which there were many.Im going to talk a little about his role in the veterans area, given my responsibility for veterans affairs. Politics is often just a lot about numbers, and for Bob Hawke the numbers were impressive: only 12 years in office, but he was Prime Minister for almost nine of those years, making him the third longest-serving Prime Minister in Australias history. He was 50 when he entered parliament, which is old by todays standards. A lot of members start much earlier than that, but he was 50, and it was his second attempt, as weve just heard. He entered parliament in 1980, but by early 1983 he was already the Leader of the Opposition for just one month, after which he became Prime Minister—probably the most remarkably short parliamentary apprenticeship of anyone, because he reached such a high level in such a short amount of time.But the numbers dont really do justice to Bob Hawke. His achievements across the board—of which weve heard many today—extended to the area of veterans affairs, and the legacy is something we should regard positively now. Many of the achievements of Prime Minister Hawke continue to benefit veterans today, in 2019. The introduction of Medicare in 1984 offered repatriation beneficiaries the choice of having their health care provided through the repatriation treatment system or Medicare, a very direct benefit to our veteran community. In 1986, the Hawke government implemented the Veterans Entitlements Act, and that was a key piece of veterans legislation which consolidated all the repatriation legislation and removed some of the anomalies, such as cancellation of the war widows pension on remarriage, to allow those widows who remarried to retain their pension. In 1988, with the introduction of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act, the compensation policy for veterans of peacetime service shifted towards rehabilitation and return to the workforce, which today we recognise as being critical elements of the overall health and wellbeing of our veteran community. And, perhaps most notably, in 1988 the gold card was extended to female veterans with qualifying service from World War II, and, in recognition of some of the past discrimination in relation to issues such as pay and access to defence service homes assistance, no age qualification was needed. I guess that, for our Vietnam veterans, the Hawke era will be remembered very much for the welcome home parade for our Vietnam veterans, which occurred in Sydney in 1987. A crowd of 100,000 Australians, including the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, was there to help try and heal the divisions which existed between our Vietnam veterans and the Australian community at that time. So, in many ways, the Hawke legacy to the veteran community was something rather substantial.In defence, Prime Minister Hawke in that time sought to strengthen the ANZUS alliance within a greater framework of Australian defence self-reliance, and he was the Prime Minister who commenced the development of the domestically built Collins class submarines and established AUSMIN, which is a routine high-level political engagement on defence and security matters with the United States. So, whether its in defence or in veterans, Prime Minister Hawkes legacy is something quite substantial.But, for me personally, I think the Hawke legacy around Landcare is something for which this generation and future generations should remain eternally grateful. It was Bob Hawke who in July 1989 made the initial commitment of $340 million over 10 years to establish Landcare. At that time, Bob Hawke said:When the earth is spoiled, humanity and all living things are diminished. We have taken too much from the earth and given back too little. Its time to say enough is enough.He said:… we are declaring next year the Year of Landcare …As I said, I think this generation and future generations owe him an eternal debt of gratitude for that decision, with this year seeing the 30th anniversary of Landcare. It actually arose from an unlikely collaboration where a joint submission from the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation led to this very practical approach to managing environmental issues. Im very pleased that this government has committed an additional $100 million in the 2019-20 budget to a new Environment Restoration Fund, which will build on our $1 billion National Landcare Program.By any measure, Bob Hawkes parliamentary career was a life of incredible service, and I guess it challenges those of us who serve here today to consider: what lessons can those of us honoured to be in the 46th Parliament, in this very first week of the 46th Parliament, learn from Bob Hawkes parliamentary career?Id like to leave that thought to the man himself to answer, because, when he was asked how hed like to be remembered, Bob Hawke said:As a bloke who loved his country, still does. And loves Australians and who wasnt essentially changed by high office.I think thats the critical point: wasnt essentially changed by high office. Id have to say to Bob Hawke: mission accomplished—and incredibly important advice to all those who serve in this place today. On behalf of the people of Gippsland, Id like to extend my condolences to Bob Hawkes family, to his friends, and to his Labor Party brothers and sisters. May he rest in peace.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Mr CHESTER (Gippsland—Minister for Veterans and Defence Personnel and Deputy Leader of the House)

name: King, Catherine, MP
content: It is fitting that were having a day of tribute, in speeches, to Bob Hawke. I think he would be pretty chuffed by that as well, and Id like to think that perhaps hes listening in from on high to all these words about him today. It was obviously a very bittersweet moment when we heard the news of Bobs dying. It is a time of great grief for the loss of the great man, a figure who was larger than life and who seemed ever-present throughout our lives, but it also is a time of great reflection and celebration of someone who has been a pretty extraordinary influence not just on the politics of Australia but on pretty much every aspect; our modern economy and our social services system have been built on the back of his legacy.Of course, as youve heard from many of the members here in this place, Bob and his voice, his actions, his words, are the soundtrack to the lives of many of us, and the soundtrack, for many of us, to our political awakening as well. I remember being at high school at the time of Bobs prime ministership and I remember one of the lovely radical Catholic nuns, who was teaching us English, talking about the accord—to a group of young women in a Catholic girls school—and saying, This is amazing. This is an extraordinary time. Labor—Labor, of all parties—is sitting down with industry and is negotiating an accord about how to grow the economy and have a social safety net for our workforce. And she was saying, Karl Marx would be spinning in his grave! This is such a historic moment. I remember that. I remember my year 12 HSC Legal Studies exam question was on the Franklin Dam case. This is the sort of backdrop to the political awakening of many in this current crop of politicians. So the emotion and passion that you hear in this place about Bob is also about our own growing-up and our own political awakening.We as a country are so fortunate that we had Robert James Lee Hawke as our Prime Minister and that he took the decision at such an early age to engage actively in a political life. That, of course, came at some cost to his kids, and to his beautiful wife, Hazel, at the time, as well. We owe a great debt to the Hawke family for allowing their dad, not often at their choice—and growing up in very difficult circumstances—to continue to have such a public political life.Hawke changed our country for the better. He set us on a new path. He gave us a new confidence and a new place in the world. His government opened our economy to the world. He floated the dollar. He pushed so many environmental agendas, saving the Franklin. He reset industrial relations. He outlawed gender discrimination in the workforce. He welcomed Chinese students after Tiananmen, and spoke up for human rights and humanity. He abhorred racism at home and overseas, and he worked tirelessly to confront poverty and address Indigenous disadvantage.When Bob entered government, 30 per cent of Australians finished year 12. That seems extraordinary today—only 30 per cent of Australian children finished year 12. When he left office, 70 per cent did. Thats a huge legacy, children finishing their secondary education and going on to do great things in and of their own right. Of course, in my previous portfolio, one where the legacy is writ large every single day when people visit their GP, is Medicare—that green card we all carry in our wallets, in our purses or in our pockets; a very important universal health insurance scheme for all Australians. And he said very much at the time when Medicare was being introduced that, without Medicare, there were some two million Australians who, in the event of a significant health event, would go bankrupt because of their health costs, and that was the reason Medicare needed to be introduced—fought by the opposite side but now embedded well and truly into our nations polity.I could stand here and talk for a long time about the many, many achievements of Hawke in the way in which he transformed our nation, and I think a lot of people have contributed in that way, but, beyond his policy achievements, I think there is something really remarkable about the man both during and post politics—about the way in which he kept that passion and fire alive but also was able to embed that in others. The Hawke government was the first Labor government that I had the privilege of voting for, once I had reached the age of 18. And, when I first ran for office back in 2001, Bob came to Ballarat to help. Hed been many times to our city before that, but he was picked up in Melbourne and driven down the Western Highway to Ballarat to campaign with me. There are many incidents and anecdotes that come from that, but, in particular, I really noticed that, wherever we walked, people wanted to come and talk to Bob. But not only that; they actually wanted to grab his hand, to touch him, to hug him and surround him, and they wanted to say things like, I was able to go to university, I was able to stay well, or, I had cancer and this is what happened to me. They wanted to tell him about what the things his government had done had meant for them deeply and personally in their own lives. And that is really Bobs legacy.He was also an incredibly funny man—just raucous, larger than life. Some of the things he did! I remember walking through our Wendouree Village—its now called Stockland Shopping Centre—with him, walking along and suddenly noticing he was no longer walking with me. Hed darted off. I looked over, and there he was in the bookshop that was there at the time, flicking through, of course, the Guinness book of records, and at the top of his voice saying, Yep, still there. My beer-drinking record is still there, much to the humour of the crowd that had gathered around him. He wanted to talk about how that was still there, and that made us laugh.In particular, there was his incredible generosity of mentoring others. He saw very much his role as an elder statesman within the Australian Labor Party. He took that very seriously, campaigning with the likes of me in my first election campaign but taking the time to stop and to talk to young people in the labour movement, spending time continuously with the ACTU and with new parliamentarians to teach us, to engender that passion for politics with all of us. Before Bob headed back down the highway in that first 01 election campaign, my campaign office was in a 100-year-old bakery—at the time, there was a big oven still upstairs. I remember him heading upstairs; he wanted to have a cigar before he headed off down the highway. He sat and held court, as Bob could do, with all of the young Labor people who had come and were helping out in my election campaign, and for an hour and a half to two hours they were transfixed, asking him: What are the important values? What are the things, the policies, we should be pursuing? And he just took his time with every one of them to talk that through. I know many of them who now have gone on to be very senior staffers within the labour movement—politicians themselves. They talk about that hour or two that they had with Bob sitting around the ovens of the old bakery as being a really important part of their own political awakening.Anyone whos met Bob would have a story just like that: that generosity, that humanity that he would pass on to everybody. So, from the people of Ballarat in particular, I do want to say we are so sad about Bobs passing. Were custodians of the Prime Ministers avenue of honour in the Ballarat Botanical Gardens, and there was an impromptu gathering. Unfortunately, I was unable to be there, but on the night that Bob passed away there was an impromptu gathering in the Ballarat Botanical Gardens in front of his statue. The group came together there to share Bobs life, to share a beer and to consider what Bob meant to them. All of those present knew that their country and their lives had been changed by the actions, the decisions and the changes brought in by the government that Bob led.One of the things that Bob was very much known for was running a very consultative cabinet process, allowing his ministers—and he had many talented ministers—to actually do the work and the policy work that was required. He really gave them their head, allowing them to develop that work. It is why people who worked with him in that era—Neal Blewett, Kim Beazley—speak of him with great fondness and strength. They know that they did their best work because they had the best leader at the time.Bob said that he wanted to be remembered as a bloke who loved his country and still does, who loves Australians and who wasnt essentially changed by high office, and I think we do remember him in exactly that way. The Bob I met campaigning back in 2001 was the same Bob I remember from my childhood. It was that love that drove him to make our nation a better place for all of us. It is why Australians, in turn, loved him. Its why people came up to him in the street and wanted to talk to him and tell him about what he had done for them.Bob wanted to be remembered for that but, in reality, he will, of course, be remembered for more. As Treasurer, Paul Keating once said:The fact of the matter is that the Labor Party makes the political heroes in this country.Reading that quote almost 30 years later, it is impossible not to think of Bob and, of course, of Paul. Bob epitomised the need to drive our country forward, that the world would not wait for us and that government is the best tool—imperfect as it can be—with which to give Australians better lives. That is the purpose that drives us all. All of us in this place should continually strive to live up to those standards, to be the representatives that Australians deserve and to have the courage of conviction to do what needs to be done.To Blanche, to Bobs children, to the late Hazel Hawke and to all of his family and his friends, I pass on my sincere condolences. Our country was very lucky to have Bob, and his legacy will last long. Particularly to Blanche I want to say: it is an extraordinary gift to be with someone in their weakest moments, but to be able to be with that person and allow them to live the fullest of lives every single day as their body fails is an extraordinary thing, an extraordinary act of compassion and love. I want to pay tribute to her particularly, and to Bobs children, not only for allowing him to die with such extraordinary dignity, surrounded by love, but also for continuing with the huge legacy that he has given to this fantastic country of ours. Vale, Bob.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Ms CATHERINE KING (Ballarat)

name: Sukkar, Michael, MP
content: I want to take this opportunity to join with my colleagues in paying tribute to Australias 23rd Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. Weve heard an array of amazing stories and anecdotes of the former Prime Minister today, and it is a fitting occasion for our parliament to set aside all other business to recognise the outstanding contribution that he made to our country and the enduring legacy that, Im sure, he and his family are proud of and will continue to be proud of.What an amazing life! He was born in Bordertown, went on to become a Rhodes scholar, was president of the ACTU, had a very short-lived period as Leader of the Opposition and then, ultimately, was Prime Minister of Australia. He had many academic achievements in his time at Oxford, some of which were augmented by his drinking abilities. He very famously drank 2½ pints of beer in 11 seconds, which I understand made it into the Guinness book of records. I suspect that probably had some contribution to his early political success and popularity.He passed up several opportunities to enter parliament before finally becoming the member for Wills. Having had many family members who lived in his electorate at that time from a Lebanese background, I can say the way he represented that community and many other migrant communities is something that to this day endures within those communities and the fact that he had an Italian pensioners club named after him. What a great reflection of just how important he was to so many of those new Australians, and that has never been forgotten.In many respects I think Bob Hawke reflects the best of what many call old Labor, and he really did seek in everything he did to represent the best interests of working Australians. He knew what made the average Aussie tick. I know thats a generalisation, but I think he really did understand what Australian people found important, what they wanted to see in a leader and he was easily able to relate to people. He wasnt aloof, he wasnt out of touch, and I think what he exuded so powerfully throughout his life was the fact he never saw himself above the average Australian punter, to use a well-worn phrase.His famous 1983 election slogan was: Bob Hawke. Bringing Australia Together. And, boy, in many respects, thats exactly what he did as Prime Minister. In fact, Advance Australia Fair, which was first adopted as our national anthem in 1984 by a proclamation of the Governor-General at the time, Sir Ninian Stephen, was on the recommendation of his Labor government. In many respects that was a reflection of the ethos: Bringing Australia Together.Many have spoken about the fact that Bob Hawke really was the catalyst, along with his Treasurer, for opening up the Australian economy, especially to Asia; floating the dollar; reforming the tax system; and privatising several large government owned businesses—many of which had the support of the Liberal opposition at the time. However, these were great achievements that I know, from many of the interviews I saw throughout his life, were a legacy that he was very proud of.Again, its been remarked on numerous occasions from this side of the House today—but I suspect many of us in the Liberal Party also believe—that Bob Hawke was Labors best Prime Minister by a long shot, and I think his record proves that. I think his connection to the Australian electorate and his ability to win four elections also prove that.Bob Hawke was also a major player on the international stage. He served our nation with distinction, forging close defence and security ties with a political hero of many of those on this side of the House, including me, Ronald Reagan, and of cordial foreign relations with another global giant of that era, Margaret Thatcher and the UK.Australians will never forget the legacy and significant achievements that Bob Hawke gave to our nation. This building that were in is a lasting testament to his foresight and vision for a modern Australia, amongst many other much more important things than the bricks and mortar of this building, but this is a visual representation of that.Can I express my deepest condolences and sympathy to his wife, Blanche, his children and grandchildren. I also recognise the late Hazel Hawke, who, for many people, was absolutely a part of the Hawke duo of his time as Prime Minister. Hazel Hawke was almost as well loved, if not more so, than Bob during those years. I can certainly attest to that from my own familys experience.As the Prime Minister recalled earlier today, Bobs mother repeatedly found herself drawn to the words of the prophet Isaiah when she was pregnant with him:For unto us a Child is born,Unto us a Son is given;And the government will be upon His shoulder.How prophetic that was to become in his life and to the betterment of our country. May he rest in peace.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Mr SUKKAR (Deakin—Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Housing)

name: Thistlethwaite, Matt, MP
content: Bob Hawke loved Australia and Australians loved Bob Hawke. Like no other Prime Minister, he personified, perfectly, the Australian culture and spirit—the larrikin leader with a big heart and a unique ability to endear people to his values, his beliefs and his partys policies. He rose to the highest office in our nation as Robert James Lee Hawke, but he was never, ever above the people. Bob was always with Australians, and Hawkie will always be with us. He was a man in tune with the Australian psyche, with a plan for a better country, a determination to deliver it and a charisma to win support for it.When I think about the Hawke era, the overwhelming emotion I feel is pride, pride in Australia and its people. Bob Hawke made us proud to be Australian. Bob and his government established a confidence in Australia and its future that we havent seen since that era of the 1980s. He campaigned in 1983 on a platform of Bringing Australia Together, but his legacy shows that Bob Hawke helped put modern Australia together. Throughout the 1980s he was Australia. Its almost incredible that wherever you go, across this wide country, almost every Australian has a Bob Hawke story, either of meeting him or of being at a particular place, remembering where you were on a particular day—particularly when we won the Americas Cup in 1983 and Bob uttered those immortal words that are now part of Australian folklore history and culture.In his early life, Bob developed a value system based on equality, advancement through education, opposition to racism, and social justice through collective rights in the workplace. When it came to these values, he never, ever waivered from them in his career in the trade union movement, and in parliament and as our nations leader. He was proud of his trade union background. Bob loved the history of the Australian union movement and all that it stood for. This came through whenever you went to a union function with Bob Hawke. Inevitably, he was up the front leading the singing of Solidarity Forever. He knew every one of the words and led that song with vigour and purpose.In his career in the union movement he used his intellect and supreme oratory skills to argue, on the national stage, for better wages and conditions for working Australians. Many of those wages and conditions that we take for granted today—things like long service leave, sick leave, annual leave and overtime rates—were established by Bob Hawke. He argued before the Industrial Relations Commission for those conditions to be put into Australian awards and workplace agreements because it was the right thing to do by Australian workers, and our economy could afford it.Bob was the master negotiator, able to lead a discussion to consensus and advancement for the workers that he was representing. No wonder he was the figurehead and leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions for over a decade. He understood, better than any other, the value of the Australian union movement to advancing the economic and social interests of Australians. He led a government that modernised the Australian economy and laid the foundations for the economic growth and living conditions that we all enjoy in Australia today. He led a government that saw Australia become an open-trading nation, that reduced barriers to trade, that introduced competition into industry, that modernised industry. He introduced the Prices and Incomes Accord, which introduced the notion of the social wage, with workers forgoing wage increases for social advancement through the establishment of Medicare and superannuation, the compulsory retirement income system. He introduced enterprise bargaining, the notion of productivity based bargaining in workplaces, which was unheard of in Australia at the time, which had a very rigid and industry based award system for conditions and the establishment of wages through awards.He was deeply interested in and saw the value of education. Theres an often quoted statistic, one that I think perfectly highlights Bobs commitment and passion for education and the advances that his government made for education in this country. When he took office as Prime Minister in 1983, Australia had one of the lowest school retention rates in the developed world—that is, the rate of people going on from school in year 10 to complete high school at year 12. At that time, 30 per cent of all students were going on to complete high school in year 12. By the time his government had finished, that figure had risen to 70 per cent. What a difference that made to productivity advancement in Australia. It was his government that kickstarted the productivity surge in Australia that has lasted for decades. As I said earlier, his government laid the foundation for the economic growth that has seen Australia record the worlds longest continuous period of growth, which is still running today. The Australian economy of today is a Labor economy. It has been the worlds best performing economy of the last quarter of a century because it was built on the notion of fairness and the value of a progressive taxation system, decent workplace conditions and wages, a living wage, and a system of government payments that were means tested and supported uplifting Australians and supported education.Bob fought for equality his whole life. He abhorred racism and discrimination, taking the fight to apartheid and bringing many more from across the world with him. He was a champion for womens equality, developing a national agenda for women and establishing the Affirmative Action Agency. The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 put outside the law gender discrimination in workplaces. His list of achievements to protect and preserve Australias environment and, importantly, on the international stage include preventing mining in Antarctica; the saving of the Franklin River, which still flows in its natural form today; recognising the threat of climate change; and establishing and growing national parks throughout the country is one of legend.Of course, the Hawke cabinet that made a lot of these decisions was one of the best. Bobs style of cabinet was to allow his cabinet ministers to do their jobs—to do the research, to do the consultation and to come to cabinet with submissions—and if the submissions were well researched, well consulted and in the interest of Australia he would back his cabinet ministers to the hilt. Something that people in the electorate that I represent, Kingsford Smiths, are very proud of is the fact that one of my predecessors as member for Kingsford Smith, Lionel Bowen, was Bob Hawkes Deputy Prime Minister for many years. In a tribute dinner last decade that Bob spoke at in honour of Lionel Bowen, he described Lionel as pure crystal, someone who was always to be relied upon and was always there as a loyal deputy and a constant source of good advice. They had a friendship that lasted for many decades and was very much valued by Bob Hawke.Like so many who have spoken before me, I have a Bob Hawke story. Bob came to the launch of my first campaign for Kingsford Smith, in 2013, to officially launch my campaign. He was 84 years old at the time, but hed not lost it one bit. He fired up and got the crowd of hundreds riled up about the potential of a coalition government and what it would do to this country. I might say that much of what Bob Hawke spoke of that day about cuts to services and the like has come true.But the incredible thing about Bob at that campaign launch—there were hundreds of people there—was that when it concluded everyone wanted to come up and touch him and shake his hand and tell their Bob Hawke story and how it made a difference to their lives. It literally took him over an hour just to get out of the venue, because everyone wanted a photo with him, everyone wanted to talk to him, everyone wanted a piece of Bob Hawke, and he was willing to oblige. Although he was tired, it was late in the day, and he had been doing some campaigning earlier in the morning—were talking about a man in his 80s—it seemed to boost him; it seemed to lift him. He got energy out of being with other Australians and hearing their stories about his era of government. Its something I will never forget. Im very appreciative of Bob Hawke for coming to my campaign launch in 2013, and I believe its one of the reasons why I did well in that particular campaign.Something else that Kingsford Smith is proud to boast of is that the Hawke legend continues in my electorate to this day, because Hawkes Brewing Company—we all know that now theres a beer named after Bob Hawke—was founded in Coogee, in the electorate of Kingsford Smith, by two young fellas, Nathan and Luke. They took the inspiration from their hero, Bob Hawke, to start an Australian beer company built on the values of that national icon. I ran into Nathan and Luke, believe it or not, on election day 2019 down at Coogee, where they were going to vote. I was on the booth handing out how-to-votes. They said to me that after voting they were going over to visit Blanche to pay their respects to her and the family not only for the legacy that Bob had left, but also for him agreeing to be the patron, if you like—the name—for their brewing company, which is doing so well. In the wake of that I said to my staff, For our election party tonight, I want you to try to buy a few cases of Hawkes lager so we can all do a toast to Hawkie tonight. They spent an hour or so scouring every single bottle shop throughout Sydney. Guess what? There wasnt one can left. Bob Hawkes lager had sold out across Sydney. I think that says everything about how much Australians loved Bob Hawke.Bob Hawke loved a beer, of course, but he loved Australia and its people even more and that made him a committed republican. For him, cutting the symbolic ties with the United Kingdom and having an Australian as our head of state was inevitable. During the 1999 referendum campaign for an Australian head of state, he argued that we didnt need more time to mature as a nation. Australia was and is a mature nation. We were ready then and were still ready now. While an Australian republic may now seem far from inevitable, we remember the long-term vision of Bob Hawke and his unshakeable faith in Australia and Australians. That is what came through in that 1999 referendum campaign—his faith in Australia and Australians.He leaves a huge legacy. He leaves so much for us all as parliamentarians to aspire to not only for what we can achieve as individuals but, more importantly, what we can achieve together as a parliament. I offer my sincerest condolences to Blanche and his family. Rest in peace, Hawkie.

Speaker: Mr THISTLETHWAITE (Kingsford Smith)

name: Joyce, Barnaby, MP
content: I rise to add my condolences to those who have spoken so well about the life of former Prime Minister Bob Hawke. I was privileged enough to be invited by Blanche dAlpuget to the funeral of Bob—obviously Bob didnt invite me. Theres something that can be said about the way the Labor Party sends off one of their champions; it was an incredible event. I just want to put on the record the endorsement that was given by so many. Probably the most memorable speech was that of Kim Beazley, which really encapsulated the strengths of his friend and colleague. It was also good to see, at that service, the capacity for old adversaries to be brought together. The reception that was given to former Prime Minister Paul Keating also made sure that an adornment of that service was the bringing together of the ends to once more make a circle, so that there would be a sense of parting, in the relationship between Keating and Hawke, in the way it commenced, which was one of friendship.As a man from Bordertown in South Australia, Bob Hawke had the capacity to encapsulate both the urbane and the regional and this carried him well through his career. He was also a Rhodes scholar, as were so many other former leaders: Kim Beazley, Tony Abbott, Malcolm Turnbull. He was also someone in whom—when people watched him on television and saw him from a distance, as people in the country did—people had a sense of pride, because he was a person who obviously had a strong intellect, and this was conveyed through a larrikin persona, but nonetheless that intellect gave people a sense of pride in his capacity to connect, especially to world leaders such as President Bush. When people observed from a distance, they could see that there was a real affinity, a real connection—that Australia, through the voice of Bob Hawke, had a capacity to reach out to other major players in the world and make us as one, and not to make us look like an appendage. He was a person who walked on level ground with these global leaders.Also, he no doubt made Australia grow up. For so long, we had had a sentimentality towards England, an attachment to England, which, obviously, in the time that Bob Hawke came about, was becoming a bit of an anachronism, and we had to make some changes. The most notable one was the Australia Act, which of course cut ties to the Privy Council. When you think about it, in 1983 it was pretty ridiculous: the idea that you were going to go and sit on a wool sack in London somewhere and make an appeal about an issue in Australia was rather absurd. And, even though there was a sense that things should remain as they were, Bob Hawke had the capacity to shake the nation and say: Its time to move on a bit. We can stand on our own two feet now.Would Bob Hawke survive today? Probably not. What weve also seen is the advent of mobile phones and the 24/7 media, where this has turned more into cheap daytime television than politics, in some instances. As to a person with the credentials of Bob Hawke but also the colour of Bob Hawke, it would be a hard ask to say whether he would survive. I noted one of the articles by Phil Coorey where he sort of disputed that, and I would say that it is a shame that the world has passed where the John F Kennedys and the Eisenhowers and the Bob Hawkes would actually be able to survive in a 24/7 media spotlight, and that what that wouldve meant for places like Australia is that we wouldnt have had a person like Bob Hawke, and we wouldnt have had what he did for Australia, which was to create an epiphany—a greater realisation that we can stand on our own two feet and be proud of who we are.In closing, Id just like to give my own experiences of Bob Hawke. I found him to give sage advice. I had the pleasure of meeting Bob Hawke a number of times. And the one thing that is not just specific to Bob Hawke but to a number of politicians is: as people ascend their political mountain, their political Mount Sinai, they go up as purists; they go up as absolutists; they go up with this sort of fervent belief. But, once they can see the vision and the view from the top, they descend more as realists; they descend more as people who can see and give credit to the strengths of both sides of the political fence. Theyre probably more honest in their political views and can sit you down—as I did once with Bob, I remember, at a lounge in Beijing—and give you an honest appraisal of politics and give you advice as if they were on your side of the political fence. So they were doing it with the best intentions at heart and on your behalf, to try and see politics through the eyes of people on your side and to try to point out what they think were pertinent issues to you. That is about it.Id like to convey, as everybody has, to the family of Bob my deepest sympathies. Even though shes passed, Id like to also once more commend the great work that Hazel did; she was greatly loved by the Australian people. Id also like to commend the great care and love that was given by Blanche dAlpuget to Bob. It was something that I noted personally in discussions with Vikki over the last part of Bobs life, that she really was a person who stepped up to the mark and made sure that the final part of his life was one of dignity, one of continued involvement with his great love of politics and other parts of life and, obviously, crosswords and other things he did on his front porch. Id also like to commend her and thank her for the work that she did.As I think Kim Beazley said when he was closing, were not quite sure where Bob finished. He was an agnostic, but where he resided at the end no-one will ever know—I suppose its the same for all of us. But Kim Beazley said in his eulogy hes absolutely certain that a person with the character of Bob Hawke would be taken into the arms of our Lord and looked after.

Speaker: Mr JOYCE (New England)

name: Rishworth, Amanda, MP
content: I am very sad but also pleased that I am getting this opportunity to speak on this condolence motion. Im sure, like most Australians, everyone has their own reasons to love Bob Hawke. There is no doubt that Bob Hawke looms large in Australia as an Australian Prime Minister that was very much loved but also deeply respected. There are many Australians, including myself, who are so grateful for Bob Hawke and his reformist agenda. Many people have benefited from everything he introduced. Whether its the introduction of Medicare, a gift of affordable universal healthcare that still every Australian benefits from; the introduction of superannuation and the dignity in retirement; the support for workers, their families; the support for education; for improving the environment; for an outward-looking foreign policy, its clear that Bob Hawke as Prime Minister achieved what we all want to achieve here—that is, leave Australia in a better position for future generations.Bob really understood that a healthy economy must work for both employees and employers and that a strong safety net is critical to a healthy nation. He gave workers what they deserved, a voice, and demonstrated that with cooperation with government, workers and business, we can achieve not only a fairer society but also a more productive society. His economic reforms with Paul Keating at the time, while difficult, did not get universal support but they have set our nation on a course of uninterrupted economic growth. But Bob was not only respected for his principles and what he delivered but was loved for his nature, his down-to-earth charismatic nature which drew people in.Bob had the ability to connect with everyday Australians. This connection did not finish when he ceased being Prime Minister but continued in the decades after. He continues to be revered by many who were too young to personally remember his time as Prime Minister but instinctively understand what a national treasure he was. His ability to connect with anyone was demonstrated in so many stories that weve heard in this place today and in the media in the days and weeks after his passing. This story has been told a few times already, but it was one that I witnessed firsthand, so I would like to recount it. It was at the end of a football match at the MCG as part of the American-Australian dialogue, when I was walking back with a group, including Bob and some of the American delegates, to catch a bus back to our hotel. The bus had not arrived, so we were standing there making small talk when we heard some yelling from a car stopped at the lights about 50 metres away. There were some young occupants, not much older than 20 years of age, who recognised Bob Hawke and began cheering and probably yelling out some other lewd comments. To the American delegations amazement, rather than ignoring this carload of young men, Bob, not wanting to wait for the bus any longer, made a beeline through the traffic to the car, with his personal assistant running behind him, and jumped into the car before the lights turned green. The American ambassador at the time turned to me and asked, Isnt that your former president that got in the car? I replied, Yes, it was, to his amazement. He followed up, Well, that just would not happen in the United States. This event not only highlighted the cultural differences between our nations but highlighted what was so special about Bob Hawke: his down-to-earth nature, his ability to connect with anyone, his popularity that had been passed down to the next generation, and probably his ability to get what he wanted as well. Needless to say, Bob did make it back to the hotel before the bus arrived to pick us up, so he certainly was able to deliver there.Bobs love for the Labor Party was also something that never diminished when he ceased being Prime Minister. Indeed, as weve heard from so many stories in this place, Bob campaigned with so many of us in many elections. For me, he campaigned in 2007, 2010 and 2013. Of course, I knew that Bob was immensely popular, but seeing it in person was a sight to behold. On one of my early campaigns, I took Bob to Colonnades shopping centre, a local centre in my electorate in southern Adelaide. We were mobbed. Everyone loved him. Everyone wanted to talk to him, and he wanted to talk to them. In that situation, it would be almost understandable for Bob to become distracted by the attention, but, as yet another reflection of his nature, he remained completely focused on why he was there: campaigning for me. He insisted that no elector could get a photo of him unless I was also in the photo, remarking to me, Well, thats why Im here. So, needless to say, every elector who was in Colonnades shopping centre has a picture of Bob Hawke in their photo album, along with me standing in the background. But I did learn quickly in the 2007 campaign, Bob did not suffer fools. After sitting down with a young journalist from a local paper, Bob could not hide his exasperation when the journalist asked him, So what brings you to Seaford shops? to which he replied. Well, I think its pretty obvious: theres an election on.I will always remember Bob Hawke for his humour, his generosity, the time that he gave to me, his intelligence, his courage and, above all, his deep, unwavering love for Australians. My condolences to Blanche, his family, his extended family and his friends. He will be sorely missed.

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH (Kingston)

name: Tudge, Alan, MP
content: Today we honour the loss of one of the political giants of our nation, Australias third longest-serving Prime Minister, an incredible reformer, an intellect and a great, authentic Australian. I never met Bob Hawke, but, perhaps like most Australians, I feel as if I know the man quite intimately. He was in some respects the only Prime Minister that I knew growing up. He became the Prime Minister when I first started secondary school and remained so well into my university years. My first recollection of him was, of course, back in 1983 in that triumphant victory that Australia enjoyed, with Australia II winning the Americas Cup against the Americans and Bob Hawke encapsulating the Australian spirit early in the morning, wearing his flamboyant jacket emblazoned with the words of Australia and really just capturing the essence of the moment for all of us.He was the type of person that could do that, bringing Australia together for those key moments. Of course, when he first became Prime Minister, as has been mentioned by many people in this chamber, he campaigned on the motto and the theme of bringing Australians together. That indeed was one of the core characteristics that he brought to his prime ministership and to the character of who he was. It was one of the reasons that Australia was enamoured with him and loved him but also one of the reasons he was able to achieve so much as Prime Minister. The keywords that he was associated with were things like consensus, accord and working together. It was in this way, working with the Australian people, with unions, with businesses and others, that he did indeed achieve so much for our nation.Bob Hawke is perhaps best known for, and I think his greatest legacy as Prime Minister of this country is, his economic reforms. They were indeed an impressive set of economic reforms. Think back about those reforms that he led: floating the dollar; deregulating the financial systems; admitting foreign banks to this country for the first time; dismantling many of the tariffs; starting the privatisation of government owned businesses; microeconomic reform in partnership with the states; and retirement incomes for all workers. Every single one of those reforms in itself is substantial. Together they completely transformed the Australian economy, opening up the Australian economy to the world and setting it up for growth that we still enjoy now through his reforms and subsequent reforms of governments which were elected beyond him. But those reforms are hard to comprehend in terms of how difficult they wouldve been to achieve and the transformation that they did have on the Australian economy.Of course, Bob Hawkes great partner in undertaking these reforms was the Treasurer and the subsequent Prime Minister, Paul Keating, who worked alongside the Prime Minister. But, as has also been noted, these reforms were also backed strongly and supported by the coalition at the time. Indeed, the shadow Treasurer for much of the Hawke era was a great friend and mentor of mine, the late Jim Carlton. He often used to say to me, when I asked him about his time as shadow Treasurer: You know what? We backed all the Hawke economic reforms. I actually used to have members of my own party come up to me and say, Why are you constantly supporting these reforms? They could have made great political mileage had they opposed those things such as floating the dollar or the tariff reductions or the like. Jims response was very straightforward: they were good reforms, they were reforms that deserved to be backed and they were the right things to do. They were indeed very good reforms, and we still enjoy the legacy of them.It wasnt just the economic reforms, though, that Bob Hawke was so well known for and led but, indeed, many social, environmental and other reforms as well. The biggest social reform was, perhaps, the introduction of Medicare—something which we still enjoy today and will be everlasting. He also introduced the HECS system into the tertiary scheme. That enabled more money to come into higher education and, through that, enabled more people to access tertiary education.His environmental record is also incredibly impressive, as many members have noted. He was also a great campaigner for Indigenous rights, as the person who set aside Uluru for the Indigenous people. One of his first actions after being elected Prime Minister was to amend the Aboriginal land rights act to return Uluru and Kata Tjuta National Park to the Anangu people. There were many other great reforms, which have been mentioned by others in this chamber as well.Bob Hawke was not just a great reformer; he was also an incredible individual. Again, this has been commented on by many people in this chamber. He was a larrikin, he was a person who enjoyed a beer and he loved his sport. He was a classic Australian in that regard, despite being an incredible academic and intellect in his own right. As the Prime Minister noted earlier today, he had a capacity to feel and not to disguise or hide his emotions. He shed tears and, at times, rose to anger. He expressed joy and he was empathic as well, but that maybe that was because he had his own share of pain. Indeed, we do know a share of that pain that he had, with his brother dying and his son dying at an early age. He had the tragedy associated with his own children as well. He did not hide that pain. He did not hide the authentic man that he was. I think that was one of the reasons that the Australian people did love him so much. It was for the reforms that he led but also the authenticity of the man he was.He was an incredible Australian, and we are right to dedicate this day in his honour. I also join the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and others in passing on my condolences to Blanche and his family. I thank them, along with thanking Hazel Hawke, for the contributions that they have made. All of us in this place know that we cant do our jobs here without the great support of the families that we have back home. Certainly, he had incredible support in Hazel Hawke during his prime ministership and incredible support in Blanche and the rest of his family as well. May Bob Hawke rest in peace.
