Speaker: Mr TUDGE (Aston—Minister for Population, Cities and Urban Infrastructure)

name: Chalmers, Jim, MP
content: Australian democracy distinguishes itself from other comparable democracies in a whole range of ways, but one of those ways is that Australians hold their leaders to a much higher standard in one key respect: we want them to be simultaneously extraordinary at the same time as we want them to be ordinary people like us. We truly want them to be a first among equals. Nobody in the history of this nation has passed this test more spectacularly and for longer than Bob Hawke, or been more admired for that than Bob Hawke.As the 29th of the 63 speakers today, Im conscious that so much has been said. There have been some terrific contributions and speeches. I want to single out my great mate, the member for Lingiari, for his speech earlier on today. They have been great speeches in tribute to Bob. While I dont agree with the member who was just up, who said that Bobs most important economic reforms were necessarily all supported by both sides of the parliament, as has been claimed again today, I dont want to dwell on that or quibble with that. I do think there has been genuine warmth from his former political adversaries. Im thankful for that, and I wanted to acknowledge that.Bobs passing on the Thursday before the election was such an emotional night for all of us who loved Bob Hawke and the country he served, and for anyone who still believes that national leadership can bring people together and lift them up in a common cause. The legacy that Bob left was unparalleled in peacetime. If you compare what he inherited in 1983 with what he bequeathed to the nation in 1991, the country at the end of that period was almost unrecognisable from what he had inherited. He had inherited a closed economy, a stagnant country and a divided society. By 1991, he had opened the economy up to the world, he had played a role in the end of apartheid and he had played a role in protecting Antarctica. There was the superannuation reform, there was Medicare and there were all of these important reforms that we treasure so much.I was talking with the member for Brand earlier on, and we were saying that even one of those legacies on its own would be enough to sustain most of the people who come here. Thinking that you may have one of those legacies in your biography by the time you finish up as a member of parliament would make most people sleep pretty easily and pretty proudly at night. But the fact that Bob, working in partnership with the great Paul Keating, was able to deliver so many of those reforms, such a broad and long-lasting legacy, is evidence of the highest imaginable standard of political leadership in this country.But beyond all the measurable things and all the tangible legacies that Bob left, there are the less tangible things as well: the unmeasurable difference that he made to the country—the change in the way we saw ourselves, the culture, the confidence and the bounce in the step that Bob gave us as our national leader. Whether Bob took on the best characteristics of this country or the country took on the best characteristics of Bob, he personified what we wanted and want Australia to be—self-assured, forward-looking, intelligent and fun as well, all at the same time.One of the enjoyable things about today is hearing about his specific connections with ordinary communities right around Australia. My community is no different in having ways that we felt especially connected to Bob. One of those ways is through my predecessor, Craig Emerson. The former member for Rankin was such a dear friend of Bobs—more like a son of Bobs than a friend, even. As I understand it, Craig was there when Bob passed from this world. He played such a supportive role with the family. He loved Bob so much and he loved Bobs family so much that he played such a supportive role in the last days of Bobs life and, indeed, in organising that truly remarkable service, that memorial, that I was privileged to be a part of and attend in Sydney a few weeks ago. I want to recognise in this place Craigs relationship with Bob and the role that he played in delivering that commemoration in Sydney.Bob also had a remarkable connection to our multicultural communities in my electorate. The first service in my part of the world recognising Bobs passing was actually at the Cambodian Buddhist temple in Marsden. They put on a service with speeches, commemorations and traditional Buddhist prayer. It was a remarkable way to celebrate Bobs life, and it was an indication for me of the different ways that he touched all of the communities that make up this country that we serve today.The first memory of my life—and Im not talking about my first political memory—the first thing I can remember in my entire life was the Americas Cup win in 1983. I was five years old. My dad came and woke me up, and, if Im remembering it correctly, it was before dawn. I think it was in September of 1983. My dad came and woke me up early and we watched Australia II cross the line and we saw that footage, which has been played almost on loop ever since Bob passed, of the remarkable jacket and the remarkable statement that he made when we won the Americas Cup for the first time in all of those years. I remember being a primary school student having the nightly news at six oclock dominated by two people—Bob Hawke, who made me proud to be an Australian, and Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who didnt make me so proud to be a Queenslander. I think, if anything, that was probably the first stirrings of a Labor heart—seeing the comparison between Bob Hawke on our news and his role in our country and Sir Joh and his role in our state.I remember borrowing the Hawke memoirs. As a high school student, I was the first the first person to borrow the Hawke memoirs from the Springwood library. I stayed up half the night for a week or so getting through the Hawke memoirs. But I didnt meet him until 2001. I met him in 2001 because I was a campaign volunteer on the Eden-Monaro campaign, not far from here, and I overheard a conversation between the campaign organisers saying that they didnt have anyone to pick Bob up from the airport. So I volunteered and I went and collected him. I took him to the Queanbeyan shops, and I had never seen anything like it at that point. I was a young PhD student at the ANU and when I took him to the Queanbeyan shops they mobbed him in ways that I had not seen before and probably havent seen since. There was one woman who got him to sign the butchers paper wrapped around a kilo of snags that she had just bought from the butcher and there was another mum who got him to sign the back of her receipt from Coles or Woollies, which shed just come out of, just so that they could prove to their friends that they had met the great man when they were at the Queanbeyan shops that day.The next year I spent proper time with Bob. I wrote for him, along with Tim Gartrell and Geoff Walsh, who I worked for at the time. We worked with Bob Hawke and Neville Wran on the 2002 review of the Australian Labor Party. I got to go around the country with Bob and also with Neville Wran. It was one of the treasured experiences of my professional life to spend so much time with those two giants, and also with Geoff and Tim working on that project. There are two stories that I remember above all about that period. The first was on the day that they were releasing the report. They were going to release it down at the Labor Party offices not far from here on National Circuit. My job was to go get Neville and drop him off at the national secretariat and then go get Bob and drop him off. I went to get Neville and, as we were getting near the Labor Party offices, we saw that there was a scrum of about 40 people from the media. Cameras, microphones and journalists were everywhere on the steps of the national secretariat. Neville said to me, Do you mind—just drop us around the back. So I dropped him around the back; we got Nifty in through the back door. I went and got Bob then. We were getting near the national secretariat, and all the journos were still there. I said to Bob, and I thought I was being helpful, Bob, well just go around the back there and well go through the back door. He said, Dont be crazy—drop me right in the middle of that mob! The difference between Neville and Bob was that Bob was desperate to talk to those 40 journalists whod assembled on the stairs.The other thing was, on the same day, probably some hours later—the wee hours of that night or the following morning—after having released this report that we wrote with Hawke and Wran, a few of the staff were out and about in Canberra. Id remembered reading in Blanches first book about Bob that, when he was a PhD student at the ANU, one night there was some kind of celebration, and he swam the length of the fish pond at University House, which is a long fish pond but not very deep. I remembered this story at the least productive time, and so we decided we would all go swim the length of the fish pond at ANU in tribute to Bob. We did that, and that was not the wisest thing Ive ever done. I can report to the House that today is a far more civilised way of paying tribute to Bob than how we paid tribute to him on that night in the freezing cold in 2002.The last time I saw Bob was on his verandah. I note that a lot of my colleagues have had the same experience. It really does go to the generosity of Bob with his time that so many of us in this place have spent one-on-one time with Bob on the verandah of that spectacular Sydney home that he shared with Blanche. Ive sat out there with him with the cigar, the crossword and the big pink milkshake. The thing that really struck me from the last time I did that, which was last year, was that I kept trying to learn from him things that he had gleaned when he was Prime Minister or things from his period when he was most active in public life. The really impressive thing though was that he only wanted to talk about the here and now or the future. He wanted to talk about where the economy was headed, where the jobs were going to come from and how Labor was going to be a party of the future and not a party of the past. It was really impressive in hindsight in particular—I was also impressed at the time, obviously. Now that I think about those few conversations that I did get to have with Bob, it was remarkable how often he was focused on what was next and not just on that remarkable legacy that he left.I think it is true that Australia is not only not the same without him in his passing but also not the same after that remarkable contribution that he made. We pay tribute to him with our words today and we treasure forever the remarkable standard that he set and the legacy that he left all of us.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Dr CHALMERS (Rankin)

name: Khalil, Peter, MP
content: With Bob Hawkes passing, weve lost one of our nations greatest—one of our greatest Prime Ministers and one of our greatest Australians. He was a fighter for a fair go for all, because he believed in us and he believed in an egalitarian Australia. He loved people, and they loved him. I confess: I loved him. I would not be here in this place as one of his successors as the MP for Wills if it werent for him. He gave my migrant family equality of opportunity, access to affordable public housing, access to health care through Medicare and access to a good education. I and millions of Australians owe him a great debt of gratitude to go with our enduring love for him.Like many of my colleagues, I caught up with Bob many times. I caught up with him a number of times over the past 12 years—more recently in his office but more memorably on that back verandah for a few beers. Knowing my work in foreign policy, he would often regale me with his stories of the work that he did and the achievements—whether it was with President Reagan, President Gorbachev, President Mandela or Prime Minister Rocard, the French Prime Minister. But when I asked him what he was most proud of, given all these great historic moments that he was part of, he thought about it and he told me that it was this: before his time as Prime Minister, only about 30 per cent of Australian kids graduated from high school, and, because of the policies he put in place as Prime Minister, after he left it was over 80 per cent. I was one of them. I graduated in 1990, a migrant kid from a housing commission. He was a legend, and it was a great honour to spend that time with him. I remember saying to him, on more than one occasion, Bob, the Australian people will never love a Prime Minister as much as they love you. He really loved that, so much so that he invited me to a round of golf. I never got a chance to have that round of golf with him, but every time he saw me after that he gave me a big hug, which was fantastic.I have the honour of representing the electorate of Wills, as Bob did. It has certainly changed a lot since Bobs time there, but the people of Wills still remember their former member and Prime Minister with great love and gratitude. Mimi Tamburrino, who worked for Bob in his electorate office for 12 years, told me about a time in early 1981, before Bob was Prime Minister, when he was just the regular member for Wills. He walked in straightaway and wanted to see her, and he said: Here, Mimi; heres 20 bucks. Go down to the TAB and put a bet each way on this horse—five bucks each way on this one and $5 each way on that one, and so on. This was a very young Mimi, and she said, All right, but what is the TAB? She had no idea. He was incredulous and he bellowed, What do you mean you dont know what a TAB is? Years later, when Bob was Prime Minister, hed walk in to his electorate office—on the occasion that he had the time—and hed say: Mimi, whats been happening in the electorate office? Are you looking after the people? Shed say, Yes, Bob, but the people want to talk to the member for Wills, and he would respond, What do they want to see me for? Youre the member for Wills; Im just the Prime Minister.So I want to thank all the people of the electorate of Wills who have so generously shared their memories of Bob with me in recent weeks. Ive had a condolence book out the front of the electorate office in Coburg, and people have left some really beautiful messages for Bobs family. Ill just read you a couple of those messages. From Julie: Bob, you made an everlasting impression on Australia. You brought the Labor Party together and showed Australia what a progressive and kind government can do. Thank you. From Donna: One less light on the hill with your passing.He changed so many lives in our local electorate of Wills, but he changed the nation. He made better the lives of millions of Australians, with the economic reforms that weve heard about, modernising the Australian economy, the foundation of our decades of prosperity; with wonderful social policy, which I touched on and which affected my family—Medicare and education; and with environmental policy—saving Kakadu, the Daintree and the Franklin and working with Prime Minister Rocard, the French Prime Minister, on saving Antarctica. That equality of opportunity, which means so much to all of us, means that much of the Australia that we know today would not exist if it were not for Bobs golden years as Prime Minister.And he changed the world for the better as well. He had a critical role in elevating Australias place in the world and a critical role in defeating apartheid. Robert Ray, one of his very talented and formidable cabinet ministers, reminded me that, above all of this, there was this immense work ethic that Bob had, to make it all possible. He had the courage of his convictions. He did what was right even when it was hard. In 1988, Bob refused to buckle on what was then the populist push for Australia to limit Asian immigration. He reaffirmed Australias commitment to an immigration system that did not discriminate based on race or ethnicity, and in the wake of the Tiananmen Square protests Bob offered asylum to Chinese students studying in Australia. That was the right thing to do. He had the conviction of his values, even if they were not popular at that particular time.That is what true leaders do—they lead. This is Bobs legacy: leadership through conviction, public service through love. That is the legacy that Ill hold on to as I go about my day-to-day work for the people I represent in my electorate of Wills and here in this chamber for the national interest.Wherever hes looking down upon us, or wherever he might be right now: Bob, we shed so many tears for you when we heard you passed. We will all remember your public service and your love for us and for our country, and we thank you for giving so much of yourself to all of us. I would not be here in this place if it were not for you, nor would millions of Australians have been given the opportunity to fulfil their potential if it were not for you. My condolences go out to the entire Hawke family and to Blanche, who told me at the memorial that it was now time to celebrate his remarkable life. I want to end with one very simple message from that condolence book left there: Bob, you gave so much to Australia and Wills. Youll be missed but never forgotten. Vale, Bob Hawke. Rest in peace.

Speaker: Mr KHALIL (Wills)

name: Templeman, Susan, MP
content: I was pretty scared the first time I phoned Robert James Lee Hawke. I was 19, it was 7:05 in the morning and my first words to him were something like: Hello, Mr Hawke. Its Susan from the Mike Carlton show. Ill put you on hold and Mike will be with you shortly. With that, I flicked him to hold, and buzzed Mike Carlton and said, The Prime Minister is on line 3. It was 1983. Yes, I was a switchboard girl for the 2GB breakfast show and, over the next two years, Bob Hawke was a not-infrequent interviewee of that gifted broadcaster. They were a good match, and I was always a little bit scared that Id lose the phone call on its way to the studio.This might have been my only personal contact with the Prime Minister, but in 1985 I found myself at much closer quarters, here in Canberra in the old parliaments press gallery as 2UEs cadet reporter. I dont think I was any less scared of the man we called Hawke in those early years, terrified that, in a media conference, I would ask a stupid question, particularly with the likes of Laurie Oakes, Paul Lyneham and Ian McMinn as witnesses—not to mention a few others who are still in the gallery today. But what I slowly understood as the years went on was that I was watching an extraordinary man in action, a man who could read an audience and, using language, intellect and performance, find a way to take them with him on a journey of change without them being gripped by fear.He wasnt a bloke I watched on TV. As a radio journalist, I was usually standing just behind his shoulder, my arm wrapped around him with my microphone being supported. I had to make sure my microphone wasnt in range of the cameras, because the camera crew got stroppy about that. It was a real physical proximity, and its one which few people encounter in their workplace. You do get to see people up really close. I got to study the back of his head and his ear at various close quarters as I recorded every word. I had a moment of horror last year when, along with two other former press gallery journalists, Anna Grutzner and Christine Wallace, I was talking to some politics students at ANU and realised we were probably considered primary historical sources for the Hawke years.The member for Lingiaris comments really resonated with me earlier today, about the way that the caucus and that government worked and the incredible people who made up the team led by Bob Hawke. My recollection is that Hawke exuded energy. I saw someone gathering people to him to work through issues, to reform whole industries, like footwear and clothing, in the fairest way. I saw women being given roles. I saw warmth and respect for people from all walks of life. I saw fierce debates of ideas, which I recall as being much more issues driven than personality driven. And, as the member for Lingiari noted, I do recall how long some of those cabinet meetings went, because the media were all hanging around waiting for them to end—but at least in those days parliament had a non-members bar!Bobs body language was rich and not always effectively captured by radio. On the days I covered question time, he would inevitably glance up at the press gallery—it was all smaller and closer than it is in here—and, before he delivered a mischievous line or a key remark, I swear you could see his eyes sparkle and a cheeky grin just at the edge of his mouth. At regular early-morning doorstops, where it wasnt pre-arranged as it is these days and we were just there in the hope that someone would say something, my reporters heart would lift when his car pulled up at the front steps, because it meant Id likely have a grab for radio that morning. I recall that, while he was often fantastic media talent, there were also media conferences where Id take my tape back to the office and have to do a lot of rolling edits to edit out long pauses to get my 30-second grab.So he was formative for me in my experiences of being a young journalist. I did my first overseas reporting trip with Hawke to New Zealand to meet Prime Minister David Lange for ANZUS discussions. The first time I flew on the VIP with him was to the special Commonwealth heads of government meetings in London in 1986 to consider the recommendations of the eminent persons group on economic sanctions against South Africa, where British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and he did not see eye to eye. In the 1987 election campaign, I jumped into a Chinook with him as the pool radio reporter to cover an announcement relating to his plan to see the Daintree receive World Heritage listing, which he achieved in 1988. He loomed large in my life, a big personality, and to see him on the international stage in later years, when I was a journalist in New York and London—his intelligence, his ability to have Australia stand tall alongside much bigger nations—was something that made you proud to be an Australian.After nearly 20 years away from the political sphere, I became re-acquainted with Bob in 2010 when he generously agreed to launch my first campaign. He came to Windsor, not an area known for its Labor roots, and after the official proceedings, which included him singing Happy Birthday to me to mark that day, we took off down Windsor Mall. As other speakers have noted, it wasnt long before one recognised him and word went out. He was mobbed, and the love for him from people of all political persuasions was palpable. Having lost the 2010 election, I sought advice from Bob: any suggestions on what I should do differently? His response? Learn to drink beer. As a non-beer drinker, Ive struggled with that one, but fortunately I have wonderful cider producers in my electorate, and thats proved a useful and enjoyable substitute. I think hed approve.At the memorial at the Sydney Opera House, I was assured by several of Bobs staff who were with him in the old parliament in the eighties, when we were there, that he would have drawn on something he often said when talking about horseracing results to remark on my recent re-election to this place: Doesnt matter if you win by a nose or a length; the bookies still pay out.Like so many people whose lives he touched, I extend my condolences to Blanche and his children and grandchildren, and Im pleased that we can have the opportunity to express how grateful we are to have been gifted with his wisdom, his love of life, his love of Labor and his love of Australia.

Speaker: Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie)

name: Elliot, Justine, MP
content: Its with great sadness but also with great honour that I rise to pay tribute to an outstanding Australian—the 23rd Prime Minister, Bob Hawke—and to celebrate his remarkable life and leadership. We all felt such a deep sense of loss in hearing that Bob had passed away on 16 May this year. In fact, that deep sense of loss was felt right across the nation, across the political divide, across families and across communities. We also felt immense pride for his great achievements and his lifetime commitment to improving our nation. Bob Hawke truly embodied what it is to be a great Australian and a great Labor man, and the fact is he so significantly changed our nation for the better, with so many of those positive changes still resonating today. So to Bobs wife, Blanche, and to all of Bobs family, we send our deepest condolences at this time and we give thanks for Bob Hawke and his wonderful legacy.Bob was a reformer through and through. He not only changed the Labor Party, he fundamentally changed Australia for the better. As Prime Minister from 1983 to 1991, Bob Hawke and his government brought in so many major economic and environmental reforms that endure to this very day. Of course, perhaps the most significant social reform implemented by his government was the introduction of Medicare, Australias first affordable, universal system of health insurance, which fundamentally improved the lives and health outcomes of millions of people right throughout this country. Bobs environmental vision was also central to his wonderful legacy. Through his leadership, his government enacted legislation which gave the Commonwealth power over World Heritage sites, thus enabling the World Heritage listing of sites such as Kakadu. And, of course, it was Bob Hawke who stopped the damming of the Franklin River; banned uranium mining in Jabiluka; and created the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, a great environmental legacy.Bob also proved that you can have a country that treats and respects working men and women with fairness and at the same time you can have an economy thats open to the world. Bob Hawke brought the nations powerful unions and big employers together in creating the wage accord. In doing this, he achieved that unprecedented level of harmony in industrial relations.Bob Hawke was praised for modernising the national economy and integrating it into a global one. It was one of his governments first acts in 1983, in which he floated the Australian dollar, and this move was one of the first in a long line of deregulation undertaken by his government. Bob Hawke paved the way for foreign owned banks and institutions to trade and operate in Australia, and, of course, he also reduced tariffs. Other economic reforms included the founding of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or APEC, established to promote participation and growth in our region.Not only did Bob Hawke address inequality in our economy and open it up to the global market; he was at the forefront of creating a better, fairer and more inclusive society here at home. The Hawke government instituted some of the strongest protections against discrimination, which still stand today. But, of course, the fight for equality did not end there. Bob knew that improving the educational outcomes of all Australians would lead to a better life for future generations and it would also strengthen our economy—things like setting a national curriculum standard for schools, establishing national training and qualifications standards and upgrading the TAFE sector, together with increased funding, all played a vital role in improving educational outcomes for our nation. So very importantly, from his time in office the percentage of students in secondary school grew from 35 per cent to 77 per cent—a remarkable achievement. Student numbers in training and vocational education rose by over 25 per cent, and university enrolments rose by almost 57 per cent. The fact is that Bob Hawkes reforms to education ensured hundreds of thousands of Australians could access the life-changing benefits of furthering their education—another remarkable legacy.All of his reforms, driven by his very core values of a fair go for all and focusing on those important matters like education, health and the environment, epitomise the Prime Minister and the man Bob Hawke. His government advanced economic reform, progressed social reform, and, of course, he is regarded as an absolute champion for protecting our natural environment. The fact is: Bob Hawke brought the Labor Party and the Australian public into the modern age. In typical Hawky style, he did it by consensus and took us all along for that journey because he understood our greatest strengths flow from unity.And Hawke was, of course, the most popular Prime Minister since the introduction of public opinion polls, and he used that popularity to create long-lasting change. To quote the great man himself, he said:The essence of power is the knowledge that what you do is going to have an effect, not just an immediate but perhaps a lifelong effect, on the happiness and wellbeing of millions of people and so I think the essence of power is to be conscious of what it can mean for others.Bob Hawke certainly had a lifelong effect—indeed, a generational effect—which has changed the lives of millions of Australians for the better. Ultimately, Bob Hawke left Australia a much fairer and much better place than he found it. Thank you, Bob Hawke, and farewell.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Mrs ELLIOT (Richmond)

name: Bird, Sharon, MP
content: I join so many in this place, across both sides of the chamber, in paying my respects to the memory of the Hon. Robert James Lee Hawke AC and acknowledge the tremendous outpouring of both grief and joy that we experienced at the Sydney Opera House at his memorial service. In many ways, Bob Hawkes political life, and particularly his prime ministership and his time leading this country, reflects so many of the significant moments in my own life. Indeed, the 1983 election, when he was elected, was my first federal election to vote in. Id just missed the 1980 election by a month. Im sure my vote would have made a huge difference to Labors cause at the 1980 election! However, I was very pleased that my first election, being the 83 election, saw the Hawke government take federal power and, more importantly, bring in a really important agenda that was about taking our nation to its potential. I think that was reflected not only in the economic, the international and the social areas but also in a really important conversation we had as a nation about what our future was. To be able to do that requires the leadership that so many people in this place have expressed, and trust, because they know that the leader understands them and that he epitomises their hopes. I think thats very much what Bob Hawke did. It was the case that so many of those changes were not easy. Looking back, it is easy to say that it was obvious and that they were the sorts of reforms that needed to happen, but at the same time they were not easy reforms, both within our own party and movement and within the national debate. It was certainly the case for me, at that point still a university student and newly married. It was tremendous to see a Labor government take that federal election.Of course, he was re-elected in 84 and, by then, I had my first son, and then he was re-elected in 1990, when I had my second son, so his prime ministership encompassed a very significant part of my adult life. I have to say that, when I was born, Im pretty certain no Bible fell open at any significant passage, so, when I voted in March 1983 as a uni student and young adult, I little imagined that I would have the great honour, through my own community, of standing in this parliament today acknowledging the enormous contribution that Bob Hawke made to this nation.It is the case that Bobs government made significant and massive reforms that established this country for a long-term future of prosperity and fairness. Those two things, which my colleagues have talked about, have been profoundly important for all of us as we, as legislators, deal with the issues that face us. They have been well canvassed. Recognising that so many of my colleagues want to speak in this debate, I just want to use the opportunity to acknowledge the legacy of, in particular—as my colleague the member for Richmond talked about—education, which I am very passionate about. I want to use the opportunity to put on the record the great love and affection that my own region had for Bob and the great commitment that he gave us consistently. As a trade union leader, he was very conscious of a region like mine and was very supportive of us as we have, in particular, mining and steel industries, in which he was significantly involved. But also, as Prime Minister, his great engagement and love of the Illawarra was very obvious.Like for so many in this place, Bob Hawke came and campaigned with me. Its hard to believe, when you listen to all the contributions, that there was only one man. Its hard to believe that there was a campaign by any of my colleagues in this place—probably only on this side of the House, to be fair—that Bob wasnt involved in. Its just an extraordinary thing. Our former leaders very often continue to support their party in that way, but the extent of what Bob did is just an extraordinary reflection of the fact he was Labor to his bootstraps. His love of the labour movement was profound. Whenever there was a call, right up to his very latest years, he was out there campaigning.Certainly for me in 2004 and the by-election in 2002, he came and he did—as everyone has put on the record—the great walk through the shopping centre, getting mobbed by people, taking the time to shake hands, to talk to everybody who wanted to talk to him, do photos and all of those sorts of things, because Bob loved being amongst the people and he loved being there promoting Labor values and Labor candidates. He certainly did that for me. He did laugh and he would often say—because I was always quite overwhelmed and appreciative that a former Prime Minister came to help me along—Of course a Hawke would come and help a Bird. He had that slightly dad joke with me on all those occasions.We really appreciated the support that he gave, but the community just reflected what so many have described as that great love affair that Australia had with Bob. Even years after he left parliament people would flock to talk to him. I just really want to record my personal appreciation for that. But in his great love for the Labor movement he also did that with the rank-and-file members. Members across both sides of the House would know about those dedicated volunteers. People like to be cynical about politics, but when you meet the rank-and-file members of the parties who are dedicated to the values, dreams and aspirations that youre trying to pursue and dont get anything out of it other than what they hope is something better for their community and their family, theyre really amazing people.Bob did the same for them in my area as well. I commented to my local media that I reckon there wouldnt be a Labor party member in my area who didnt have a photo with Bob Hawke, because whenever he was there he took the time to thank them for their support and efforts on behalf of the labour movement. I would like to use the last little bit of time to share some of their reflections, because I feel that this moment is as much theirs as it is mine as their representative. Chris Lacey is the president of the Thirroul branch. The Thirroul branch had its hundredth-anniversary dinner, and Bob Hawke came down and was the guest speaker. We had the obligatory singing of Solidarity Forever but he didnt just pop in, do a speech, sing a song, thank everybody and head back to Sydney; he stayed, signed books, shook hands and took photos. Chris says:Throughout his long life, Bob Hawke always had strong connections to Illawarra workers. His government saved the steel industry and played an important role in shaping modern multicultural Australia. In Thirroul we remember his involvement in our centenary celebration as a Labor branch and his memorably leading a rousing rendition of Solidarity forever.Gino Mandarino, who is secretary of the Wollongong branch, said:I first met him 32 years ago and numerous times over those decades. Bob inspired my interest in politics and public policy. He exemplified Bagehots view of great prime ministers as men of commonplace opinions and uncommon administrative abilities. Bob Hawke was the best of the best, and like Whitlam and Wran, Labor leaders of the modern era, he now joins them of belonging to the ages.Leighanne Hunt, who is secretary of the Port Kembla branch, said that Bob Hawke is the very definition of a conviction leader. Jess Malcolm-Roberts, secretary of Balgownie branch, said:Bob Hawke didnt beat around the bush or pretend he was something he wasnt. Even though people might not have agreed with his position, they respected him for being genuine and it is this that Australians value the most. His policies shaped Australia into what it is today, bringing in many of the essential reforms my generation takes for granted. The Labor movement and all Australians are fortunate for having had him as our PM.Dr Rowena Ivers, of the Thirroul branch, said, Thanks to Bob for Medicare—the gift that keeps on giving.I extend, as have so many in this place, my deepest condolences to Blanche, to all Bobs family and to his very many millions of friends around the country, so many of whom live in the Illawarra, and also pay respect to the great partnership he had with Hazel Hawke in that enormous period of leadership for our nation. I recognise Hazels role in that. My deepest condolences: we are all so much better off for the life of Bob Hawke.

Speaker: Ms BIRD (Cunningham)

name: Zappia, Tony, MP
content: Im pleased to follow the member for Cunningham in speaking to this condolence motion honouring the life of Robert James Lee Hawke, Australias 23rd Prime Minister and Labors longest-serving Prime Minister, who passed away on 16 May this year aged 89 years. I extend my sincere condolences to all of Bobs family members for they have lost the most and gave up so much of their time through Bobs public life. But he did his family and his country proud, and he will forever be one of Australias favourite sons.Bob entered public life as ACTU president in 1969. He was elected to federal parliament as the member for Wills in 1980. He became Labors leader and Prime Minister in 1983, serving as Prime Minister until December 1991, and ended his parliamentary career in 1992. That was just over 12 years of service as a parliamentarian, When I think back at what he achieved in those 12 years, it is indeed extraordinary.I note in particular that Bob was the only Prime Minister born in South Australia—in Bordertown. Whilst he didnt enter parliament as a South Australian member, there were rumours that he was looking at the safe Labor seat of Bonython in the late 1970s, with the backing of the very influential Mick Young. The seat was subsequently taken by the then Senate hopeful Neal Blewett, who, rumour had it, switched from his Senate aspirations in order to prevent Bob from taking that seat. The irony in that story is that Neal went on to serve in the Hawke government as minister for health and oversaw the reintroduction of the rebadged universal health care we now know as Medicare, for which Bob is perhaps best remembered, and which the coalition pledged to do away with at that time and at each of the subsequent elections of 1984, 1987, 1990 and 1993. After four failed attempts, I suspect that John Howard realised the foolishness of persisting with the attack on Medicare.Since his passing, much has been said about Bob Hawkes political legacy and there is widespread agreement that the governments he led between 1983 and 1991 served Australia well and introduced groundbreaking reforms that were in the national interest and continue to be so. It would be fair to say, however, that he also led a very competent team of ministers. And because Labor had not been in government for long in the post-World War II years, there was so much to do. Hawkes government got on with the job of transforming the economy, changing environmental laws, changing industrial relations in this country, and increasing and improving the health services of all Australians. Others have spoken at length about his intervention in Indigenous affairs, and we even had a new national anthem introduced under his leadership.Bobs strength, however, was his ability to bring Australians together. He knew that, if everyone was on board, more could be achieved and everyone would prosper. Its a rare characteristic that I have not seen matched by any other national leader since. Bob had good political judgement and a good political mind. But it was his ability to connect with every sector of society, and to win over their trust, that made him successful and respected. People felt comfortable with Bob Hawke. He was one of us, regardless of who he mixed with.It was a unique personality trait that I saw for myself when Bob Hawke joined me on the campaign trail in Makin in my first two election campaigns. We just heard the member for Cunningham talking about her experiences with Bob, and I can say it was exactly the same when he came to Makin. It was as if he knew the place and it was his own home turf. We visited workplaces, community centres and shopping centres. Wherever we went, Bob was completely at home and people felt equally comfortable approaching and speaking to him. They wanted to meet him. He inspired people, and they trusted him. He was still incredibly sharp and had not lost any of his political wit, even though it had been years since he had been Prime Minister of this country, nor had he lost his confidence or his skill in responding to the many media inquiries. To this day, I still cross paths with people from Makin who fondly recall Bobs visit there. I will personally cherish my own memories of our campaign time together, and I thank him for his support in my own journey to this place.The general public perception of politicians today is not good, yet in the days following his death, when people were frequently commenting about Bob Hawke, I didnt hear a single detrimental comment about him. That in itself is unique—that no-one had anything bad to say about him, and I spoke to a cross-section of people throughout my electorate. Regrettably, it is often only when a person dies that we take the time to reflect on what we have lost and the contribution that person made to our own life and to the lives of others. So, as we all reflect on the life of Bob Hawke and turn our minds to his contribution in public office, it becomes more clear than ever before that our nation is a better place because of him, that he was one of a kind and that we could all learn from him.As important as they all were, it was not, however, Bobs governments achievements that he will be remembered best for but his persona: the beer-drinking, sport-loving larrikin who was just as much at home at an Aussie barbecue or in the front bar of the pub as he was in the mansions of millionaires or on the international stage with the leaders of the world. He endeared himself to the Australian people to an extent that few others have, and, not surprisingly, thousands of people attended or watched telecasts of his funeral service. Bob Hawke, the peoples Prime Minister, has passed away, but his legacy will endure, and he will be remembered affectionately for decades to come. Vale Bob Hawke.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Mr ZAPPIA (Makin)

name: Gosling, Luke, MP
content: As many other speakers have said, Bob Hawke was a great Australian. He understood the Australian people, and the Australian people loved him for that. He was one of us. He could relate to anyone. But, as well as being a fine Australian and one of us, he was a great internationalist. He was a confident and respected advocate for Australia and championed Australia being an influential middle power in international forums. One of his earliest motivations for joining the Labor club at UWA, the University of Western Australia, was his interest in Labors and Arthur Calwells immigration policies. This led him to form an international club at the uni. He also saw the immigration policy as good economic policy as well as being good values based humanitarian policy.Bobs father, Clem, was a Congregational minister, and Bob loved Clem. Often—and in my case its the same—we take our religious beliefs, our values, from our parents, and Im sure that that was the case with Bob. He was active in the student Christian movement and the Congregational Youth Fellowship. I understand from my research that Bob was actually impressed with some aspects of the Catholic faith, but he never pursued that. But he did head off to India for the World Conference of Christian Youth, and he was shocked by the huge gap between rich and poor and also the apparent indifference of some of the conference delegates to those people in dire poverty around them.As a Rhodes scholar at Oxford he met bright young people from all around the world. I congratulate the government on establishing the Bob Hawke scholarship for the education of bright young Australians at fine overseas institutions. I think its important.Back in Australia, Bob at the ACTU and then through the International Labour Organization quickly became involved in international issues, becoming a strong supporter of Israel. Bob advocated for Russian Jews who were being denied permission to emigrate to Israel and led a strong union campaign of opposition to the South African Springboks tour of Australia. This was a significant shift in international opposition to apartheid in South Africa, which Bob continued as Prime Minister, and which led to mutual respect and friendship with Nelson Mandela. Bob was solid on the US alliance. Western Australian Governor Kim Beazley pointed me to Bobs autobiography where, in part, he said:I was a vocal opponent of the war and of US policy in Vietnam but my attitude towards America remained positive. To me, the overriding importance of Australias US alliance was clear. The United States, whatever its mistakes, was the bulwark of the free world.Bob also foresaw the rise of Asia and of China and he understood that coming rise better than most. After the massacre at Tiananmen Square Bob, as Prime Minister, invited Chinese students in Australia to stay on if they wanted to. These people, these Chinese citizens who stayed in Australia proved to be an enormous asset to Australia. Bobs act of leadership demonstrated his commitment to a multicultural Australia. I wont go into them much, but weve heard much about the reforms of the education sector that meant more high school graduates and more university graduates.The Hawke governments reform of the Australian economy, particularly the floating of the dollar, transformed us into a globally competitive trading nation. Bob was a great Prime Minister and a great Australian leader, as demonstrated by his actions both at home and abroad. He made us a more confident and outward looking nation. My earliest memory of Bob was when we won the Americas Cup in 1983. I had just turned 12 years old. I remember it being early morning, and we were watching the victorious crew of Australia II and our Prime Minister. I remember bounding out of our house to catch the school bus, and I was so proud. I can remember my heart being so full of pride, seeing that crew and our Prime Minister. I remember thinking, Australians can do anything, and I remember thinking to myself by extension as a young lad growing up in a country town—not in the city, not from a privileged family—that I could do anything. That was the feeling he gave me. Ill never forget how that made me feel.I want to acknowledge Bobs love of the Territory as well. Ive received many messages from people in Darwin and Palmerston, my electorate, and from Territorians elsewhere about how much they loved Bob. Weve heard something from my friend and fellow Territorian the member for Lingiari and others about the handing back of Uluru to its traditional owners and how important that was, about the extension of the protections of Kakadu and, of course, about when Bob received the Barunga Statement.My friend Father Frank Brennan reminded me today that it was in August 1988 in this place that Prime Minister Bob Hawke proposed that the first item of substantive business in this new Parliament House would be around reconciliation with First Nations people. The idea for the motion arose when the heads of Australian churches issued a statement titled Towards reconciliation in Australian society at the beginning of the year of the bicentenary. For the record, this was the motion:That this House—(1) acknowledges that:(a) Australia was occupied by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thousands of years before British settlement at Sydney Cove on 26 January 1788;(b) Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders suffered dispossession and dispersal upon acquisition of their traditional lands by the British Crown; and(c) Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders were denied full citizenship rights of the Commonwealth of Australia prior to the 1967 Referendum;(2) affirms:(a) the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage; and(b) the entitlement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia; and(3) considers it desirable that the Commonwealth further promote reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.Bob remained committed, and I saw that commitment just in recent times in the Northern Territory. The Barunga Statement always stayed with him. In fact, he gave his resignation speech from the prime ministership in front of the Barunga Statement in this building.My most recent memory of Bob was a simple interaction when we travelled to Arnhem Land for the Garma Festival, hosted by the Yolngu people, where he was continuing to promote reconciliation. We were going through the airport in Nhulunbuy—or Gove as some people might know the town—in Arnhem Land, and when he went through the security screening Bob was pulled up by security for having two cigarette lighters in his pocket. Only one cigarette lighter was allowed per person and he was asked by security to surrender one. Bob didnt make too much fuss about this, but I could see that he was slightly frustrated. I leaned in and said, Bob, Id be honoured to receive one of your lighters. He simply turned to me, smiled and said, Thanks mate. And I said, No, thank you, Bob. He smiled with that twinkle in his eye and I was a 12-year-old kid again. It was like when I bounded out of our house after seeing our Prime Minister with the Americas Cup. Bob looked at me and said, Thanks mate, and I just felt really special.And I guess that was Bobs wonderful gift to Australians—he made all of us feel so special and so proud. Vale, Bob Hawke. My condolences to all who loved him so much.

name: Swanson, Meryl, MP
content: And his ghost may be heard as you pass by that billabong. Bobs voice echoed out across the room as he remembered every verse of Waltzing Matilda. We were all captured by him and his incredible voice. It was 2014 and he was, as usual, singing Waltzing Matilda at the Jack Newton Celebrity Classic golf tournament. He was the patron of what has now become known affectionately as The Jack. In 1983, when Bob Hawke became Prime Minister, Jack Newton asked Bob to become the patron of The Jack celebrity golf tournament. Bob relished that job. He turned up almost every year, and almost every year he sang Waltzing Matilda at the dinner. We just loved him doing it. He understood Australians and Australia. He loved us and we loved him.I didnt know Bob particularly well or for very long. In fact, I only met him for the first time in 2014. It was when I was playing golf up in the Hunter, and when Bob made the annual trek up to The Jack. That evening I received a phone call from one of the organisers of the tournament to say that Mr Hawke had noticed me out on the golf course and wondered if Id like to have breakfast with him the next morning and have a chat about golf, because hed learnt that I was a keen golfer and had known Jack Newton for a number of years, and his lovely wife, Jackie, as well.I jumped at that opportunity and fronted up, bright and early, the next morning to have breakfast with Bob. It was just the two of us and an incredible moment in my life. We chatted about many things, with much of the conversation being around golf. We talked about politics, we talked about Australia and we talked about my love of economics as a schoolgirl. In fact, in 1983 in year 7, Mr Kemp, my teacher, had meticulously instilled in us the lessons of the accord, the deregulation of the banking industry, the floating of the Australian dollar, the opening up of Australias economy. That instilled in me a great love of economics and, of course, Bob Hawke.I went on to study economics, including three-unit economics, right through school and my HSC. I always had the great pairing of Hawke and Keating in my mind as I trawled through those essays. I told Bob about that. He was mightily chuffed that my economics teacher had really deified Bob in my mind as a schoolgirl. We also talked about the influence of China on him and, importantly, Asia generally. He really understood our country and our place in the world and he spoke to me about how important it would be for us to continue with that engagement of Asia, while still recognising the importance of the alliance with the Americans.After wed chatted for probably half an hour or 40 minutes, we both knew that we had to finish our breakfast and go and tee off. He said to me, Meryl, have you ever thought about politics? I said, Actually, Bob, Id like to do that one day. But Ive got a family and Im working in the media, working on radio, and I love radio. He said, You know what? Politics needs good strong women like you, good communicators. You really should give it some thought. So when the opportunity came up in 2016 for me to run for the seat of Paterson I had those words of Bob Hawke ringing in my head. I thought, Maybe I should just listen to this knowledgeable and great man. Maybe I should just take up the challenge of politics. So in his own way, he had a direct influence on me being here in this place today, and for that I will be eternally grateful.May Bobs ghost be heard around this place as we go about governing this great nation of ours. May we continue to grow his legacy. Vale, the great Robert James Lee Hawke AC.

name: MemberContinuation
content: Ms MURPHY: Early one morning in September 1983, a sports-loving and somewhat argumentative nine-year-old girl was utterly convinced that her new Prime Minister had just given her an iron-clad argument to stay home from school that day. I said, Hey, Mum, you know how you always say youre the boss of me? Well, if you try to make me go to school today youre a bum. It turns out that line worked so well for Bob Hawke but not so much for me. Off to school I went.He didnt get me out of a day of learning, but Bob Hawke, with his now infamous response to our victory in the Americas Cup, had given me my first political memory and one of my first debating defeats. Many more with my mother were to come. And he gave me and very many other Australians, and not to mention people from across our region and the world, so much more. My generation, whose formative teenage years were that remarkable and somewhat maligned decade of the 1980s, had the privilege of growing up while Bob Hawke; his Treasurer, Paul Keating; and his very talented government transformed our country. It did not matter that, for most of us, the closest we ever got to Bob Hawke was the nightly TV news. His presence, his personality and the pure Bob Hawkeness of him meant that we knew that he was our Prime Minister not just the Prime Minister.That charismatic presence, which so many people have spoken of in this place today, was undoubtedly one of Bob Hawkes greatest gifts. But, in my humble opinion, having that great gift was not the most important thing about him. In my view, it was what he harnessed that great gift to achieve that was most important and who and what he harnessed it for. Of course, he harnessed it for the transformational policy reforms which, as we all know, spanned the economic, the environmental and the social policy realms and which are on both the domestic and the international stage.There was also something else that he gave us which I value to this very day: Bob Hawke demonstrated to Australians that our federal government could and should be compassionate and expansive. He demonstrated that it could not just talk about equality but fight for it, particularly for those in our community who dont have the power or the resources to fight for it on their own. He demonstrated that it could take everyone on a journey of bold and progressive change that was based on a love of Australia and Australians and an unwavering commitment to equality and justice. For some of us who grew up in the magnificent eighties and whose conscious experience of politics and government was dominated by Bob Hawke, he gave us a lasting, enduring belief that that is what a federal government always should be and do. For a lot of us, he gave us a beating Labor heart, and we will forever be grateful.The first Labor member for Dunkley, the wonderful Bob Chynoweth, was first elected to the Australian parliament in the 1983 Hawke slide. I know Bob would have loved to have been able to speak today. Im pretty sure he would have told this story better than me, but I will do my best. Newly preselected to a seat that we had lost in a by-election mere months earlier and thrown into a snap election, Bob Chynoweth received a visit from the great man early on in the campaign. Hawkie inquired, How are you doing, Bob? Im just really hanging on to your coat-tails, to tell you the truth, the ever-humble Chynoweth confessed. Bobs response was: Dont worry, mate. So is everyone else. Im so glad, and Im sure were all so glad, that everyone was.We have heard a lot today about how the Hawke government and Hawke personally protected Antarctica. It was the wonderful Bob Chynoweth from my electorate of Dunkley who, years after he was first elected, went on a parliamentary delegation to Antarctica and had a personal epiphany. In his words, he sat there and said: We have magnificent places like this. We must protect them. Bob, when he returned back to our community and then to Canberra, started a campaign to influence the Hawke government and its cabinet ministers to reverse Australias position, as it was then, on the mineral convention. Bob Chynoweth lobbied cabinet ministers, but he also collected more than 20,000 signatures of Australian citizens and tabled them in this place, asking for Australias position to change.When that went before the Hawke cabinet, as we all know, Hawke took up that challenge. He took up that challenge and he fought for something that was right, something that was lasting and something that was a legacy. My community are very proud of the role that our former Labor member for Dunkley played in that legacy. But its not just a legacy of great policy; it is a demonstration, an illustration, of what Bob Hawke taught people of my generation, and some of our parents, to expect from their federal government—that is, to identify what is important and what is right, and then to fight for it, even if fighting for it is hard; even if vested interests and the rules of the game say that you shouldnt; even if you have to battle to take others, including the electorate, with you.Bob Hawke was Australias greatest Prime Minister. And while the generations that came after me didnt get the opportunity to live under his government, to this day they are no doubt continuing to benefit from the reforms that were put in place, and so will the generations to come. The great Bob Hawke will always be loved, and he will be missed. His legacy will live on. It will live on in the way he changed our country, and in the way he influenced the political philosophy of so many Australians—Australians that I am proud to say are like me. On behalf of my community of Dunkley, and on behalf of Bob Chynoweth, condolences to Bob Hawkes family and to all who loved him.

name: Leigh, Andrew, MP
content: At the outset, may I pay tribute to the member for Dunkley on a terrific first, but not inaugural, speech. It was a great tribute to Bob Hawke.He drinks like a fish, swears like a trooper, works like a demon, performs like a playboy, talks like a truckie—and acts like a politician. Almost your cliche Aussie. Except in this case its Bob Hawke, and the only typical thing about him is the way hes larger than average in almost everything. Bob Hawke is your typical Australian, oversize.If you want to understand Australias 23rd Prime Minister, you can do no better than to read Craig McGregors 1977 profile. Its a time when Bob Hawke isnt Prime Minister, hes not even in parliament—hes running the ACTU—but its an extraordinary insight into the man.Craig McGregor follows Hawke for a few days, and in part of it he tells the story of Bob popping into a bar in Melbourne for a quick five-minute chat. Two hours and half-a-dozen drinks later, Hawke starts to leave. As McGregor recounts:… he is the focus of a great deal of affection right across the spectrum: men, women, workers, sportsmen, businessmen. It buoys him up, even exhilarates him, but he remains easygoing, serious, arguing or defending himself when necessary.McGregor tells the tale of Ron Barassi and Hawke running into one another in Melbourne and how:… an elegantly dressed woman in huge, fashionable sunglasses … throws her arms around—Hawkes neck—and gives him a warm, sensuous kiss.Hawke replies:… Theres some bloody hope for Australia when women prefer politicians to footballers!And McGregor concludes with a description of a Hawke press conference. He says:… a press conference by Hawke isnt just a conference, its a media extravaganza, a glamourfest, a promotional wonder like those MGM spectaculars of old, in which Hawke plays King to his adoring court, fences and jibes with his carping Lords, puts down the media Fool, works himself into a lather of anger at The Enemy Outside, and finally sends his audience home, as after an Aristotelian tragedy, exhausted, admiring, and experiencing the exquisite pleasure of catharsis.In his 3,207 days as Prime Minister, Bob Hawke saw Australia through an accord, ACT self-government, saving the Franklin, banning uranium mining in Jabiluka, handing back Uluru to its traditional owners, establishing APEC, an economic summit and floating the dollar. And there were many reforms that were not supported by the other side of the House: the Sex Discrimination Act, Medicare, capital gains taxation, fringe benefits taxation and asset-testing the pension. But the one reform I want to focus on today was his opening up of the Australian economy by bringing down the tariff walls.When I was at university I wrote, in 1994, an honours thesis on trade liberalisation and the Australian Labor Party. I was puzzled as to why Australia brought down our tariff walls not because other countries were going to do it as part of a deal, but unilaterally. And why in other countries it had been conservatives that brought down the tariff walls, whereas in Australia it was a party of the Left.In 1994, 25 years ago, Bob Hawke was good enough to sit down with me for an interview. He told me that his commitment to tariff cuts went right back to when he was studying economics at the University of Western Australia in 1951-52. He said, I was intellectually a free trader from my earliest thinking days. I asked him about the extraordinary moment in 1973 when Whitlam cut tariffs by 25 per cent without consulting Hawke, and Hawke, as the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, put out a statement which cautiously defended it. He told me his philosophical belief in the need to reduce industry protection meant that he agreed with the principle of the decision. It is hard for me to think of a trade union leader in the modern era who would have such a response to a unilateral tariff cut which he got no warning about beforehand.He not only was ahead of his time but was also a markedly different trade union leader in his approach to modernising the Australian economy. In late 1983, he was talking about the importance of reducing tariff rates for the sake of Australian industry. He argued protection had dulled the entrepreneurial spirit and reduced the competitive pressures for high performances by a number of Australian manufacturers. His government was to go on and cut tariffs in 1988 and again in 1991. He said that in his view the most central reason for wanting to cut tariffs was that Australia was at our best when we engaged with the world. He told me: Im basically an internationalist. As I said in the very first days of becoming Prime Minister, Australias future involves becoming more enmeshed with Asia. You cant pursue that policy of enmeshment behind high tariff walls. As his former speechwriter Stephen Mills said, In Hawkes mind, resurgent protectionism, if not adequately restrained, threatened the very peace and security of the world.Australia is better off because of so many achievements of the Hawke government, but in his leadership in trade liberalisation he modernised the Labor Party as much as in any other issue. It brought a greater dose of competition to the economy and it reminded us that to be a social democrat, to be a progressive, to be a member of the Labor Party, is to be an internationalist—to believe that Australia is at our best when we choose openness.Bob Hawke was a great leader and a great internationalist. He changed Australia and Labor for the better. May he rest in peace.

name: Kearney, Ged, MP
content: I am honoured to rise to speak today to the condolence motion on the death of Robert J Hawke. Id just like to say that this is my very first speech at the dispatch box as a shadow assistant minister and Im very pleased that it is on this motion. Its an honour and a privilege to have held the same office as such a great man—President of the ACTU. Recently, at his memorial service in Sydney, I was lucky enough to have a chat with his daughter Sue, who seems to me very much like her father. She told me that people used to ask her, What is it like growing up with a Prime Minister for a father? She said she would reply by saying, Actually, I grew up with a trade unionist as a father. He always was and always will be a unionist first and foremost. Id like at this point to offer my condolences to Bob Hawkes family.As a past ACTU president myself, Id like to use this moment to reflect on his time at that great institution, the home of the trade union movement. He started there in 1958 as the ACTUs first paid researcher and advocate, and in those halls of the arbitration commission, as it was called then, he quickly became widely recognised as the industrial relation systems best advocate. He and his trusty colleague Ralph Willis, who became a lifelong friend and colleague, would take on highly paid and fussy QCs. Advocating with assiduousness but also with alacrity and without fear and without reverence—but always with respect—he formed firm friendships and connections. His network was vast across unions, businesses, politics and broader society. He ran many famous and successful cases on behalf of trade unions and their members. My good friend, Zelda DAprano, who died very recently, worked for the Meatworkers Union and infamously chained herself to the Commonwealth buildings in Melbourne to raise the issue of equal pay for women. She was in the arbitration commission the day the union won the landmark case for equal pay, with Bob Hawke acting on behalf of the union. Ive noticed that she appears in all of those iconic photos of that day with Bob. It was, of course, an outcome as a result of Zelda and her fellow feminist activists, but it was also a victory for the ACTU and Bob, who navigated the intricacies of the industrial legal case and won. Mind you, he was not one known for promoting women at the ACTU, one thing that I took up with him once when we were campaigning together in Macquarie for the excellent Susan Templeman in 2016. He did sort of agree with me that that was the case, but he said, Ged, there just didnt seem to be any women around in those days to do those jobs. On seeing my response—my raised eyebrow and the look on my face—he quickly acknowledged that he was obviously being very short sighted. He battled demons of course and he was very human, but he seemed to be a human we constantly forgave.Most Australians saw him as a normal person—one of them. His love of horseracing is now legendary. If you do the tour of Old Parliament House, they sometimes tell you how he sat at his desk in his office every single morning at exactly the same time and had a cuppa and a cigarette to study the guide and get his bets on. He did this so regularly that he was deemed a security risk. You see, he sat with his back to a great big window that could easily be seen by snipers who knew his routine, but he absolutely refused to do it anywhere else or at any other time.Ralph Willis tells the story of Bob winning Father of the Year. Although the bestowers of the award thought it was a good idea, apparently Hazel Hawke did not. Ralph said Bob had an inkling Hazel would not so be happy and asked Ralph and his wife to go home with him that night. On entering the house, Ralph said they were greeted with flying missiles thrown at Bob by Hazel, swearing loudly about his prize and making it very clear she didnt think he deserved it. So, yes, he was human, but we know, in fact, in our eyes, he was superhuman.Bill Kelty said that when Bob became president of the ACTU, we had seen nothing like him ever before. He tackled massive issues from there. As well as finding ways through difficult industrial disputes and issues, Bob, for example, took on the big retail and price maintenance monopolies. He thought big and he acted big. He maintained the roles of president of the ALP and the ACTU at the same time, and, as we heard this morning, he joked about being able to ride two horses at the same time in the circus. But, for me, this was a golden achievement. Not only workload wise but in a very public demonstration, he showed that we are a labour movement together—political and industrial arms working towards the same goals. Thats something I believe, passionately.Bob Hawke raised the broader political consciousness of the union movement at that time. He argued in one trade union support to campaign against apartheid and such was the Australian union movements impact on that issue that Nelson Mandela visited Australia first off the rank after his release from prison to thank the trade union movement.Bob threw himself into the worlds troubles. He was on the governing body of the International Labour Organization in the position I held. I know the vital nature of its work only too well. He was still spoken of almost in hush tones at the ILO when I was there. Australia is still looked to in that place for leadership and big ideas. The links with world employers, unions and governments that he formed at the ILO were great practice for Bob for when he became Prime Minister. That period prepared him well for the transition to leading his country where he so ably managed massive objectives, such as establishing APEC. He took up hard issues and he was revered worldwide.He left the ACTU in the capable hands of the amazing Bill Kelty, who had learned from him and continued to work with him and his government. They continued with that great view that the labour movement was best when the labour and political arms worked together.Ill finish by remembering what Kelty said about Bob Hawke. He said Bob had an undiluted belief in the power of education, an undiluted belief in the power of democracy and a belief in unions and the ALP and this thing he called Australia—not simply a piece of geography but a belief. I agree with Kelty. Bob did this country a power of good, did working people a power of good and did many right around the world a power of good. Thank you.

name: Watts, Tim, MP
content: Today the parliament is farewelling a giant of Australian politics and one of our great leaders. Bob Hawke will be remembered in many ways: as a Rhodes scholar and a man of the people, as a drinker and a teetotaller, as a social reformer and an economic reformer, as a larrikin and an international statesman, and as a rogue and a bleeding heart. Like all of the greats, he contained multitudes. He was a lover of Australia and its people, but he was a man who loved Australia enough to want to change it. And what a legacy of change he left—floating the dollar and opening the Australian economy to international competition and competitiveness; the accord; Landcare; the Sex Discrimination Act; saving the Franklin River, and World Heritage preservation; lifting the proportion of Australians who finished school from three in 10 to eight in 10; APEC; and giving Australia our own national symbols and anthem, and green and gold as our national colours. He was the architect of modern Australia and he was the painter of a vision of a nation who could dream of bigger things. He achieved all of this because he was a leader. He was famously committed to consensus, a consensus model of leadership. He brought Australians with him as he changed the nation.But the changes that Hawke implemented were not uniformly supported in this parliament or in this country when Hawke embarked on them. Indeed, I was amused to come across this press release from John Howard at the time, criticising Bob Hawke, Mr Hawkes obsession with consensus harming tax reform. John Howard said:Mr Hawke must drop his obsession with consensus. That this is nothing but Government by lowest common denominator is vividly demonstrated by the current tax debate.Thats the tax debate that introduced capital gains tax and fringe benefit tax that those opposite sometimes like to claim that they supported, when really John Howard couldnt even give support to consensus.The conservatives fought Hawke every step of the way, and theres no greater example of this than Medicare. Hawke fought for Medicare because he knew that no society without universal health care could be a fair society, but he was resisted at every step. Before Hawke became leader, Labor had campaigned for universal health care in the 1969, 1972, 1974, 1975, 1977 and 1980 elections, and it had been opposed by conservatives at every turn. Whitlams universal healthcare legislation was defeated three times by the conservatives in the Senate, and he was forced to call a double dissolution election to obtain the support of the parliament to pass the legislation creating Medicare in a joint sitting of parliament. Even then, at the first opportunity, when Whitlam lost government, the conservatives tore it up. This was the level of opposition that Hawke faced, but he overcame it. The conservatives continued to oppose his Medicare at the 1983, 1984, 1987 and 1990 elections. But Hawke beat them at every turn and forced a change in the terms of debate, and, by 1996, the conservatives could not win an election in this country without repudiating their previous public opposition to Medicare. Hawkes leadership established a legacy that is the envy of the world: Medicare, a universal healthcare system that delivers better health outcomes at a lower cost than nearly any other country in the world.Bob was a consensus leader, but, when he couldnt get consensus when it really mattered, he led by taking a stand. There are many Hawke achievements being celebrated here today, but I will always be personally thankful that, when John Howard said that too many people like my family, Chinese Australians, were coming to Australia, Bob Hawkes leadership stopped him dead. When in 1988 John Howard broke the consensus on a racially non-discriminatory immigration policy by calling for an open debate on levels of Asian migration to Australia and arguing that, in his view, it should be slowed down a little so that the capacity of the community to absorb it was greater, Hawke took a stand. In the first suspension of standing orders debate in this parliament, in this chamber, at the despatch box, Hawke called Howard to account. But he did so in a way that allowed consensus to be restored in the aftermath of the debate. Hawke told this House:One of the great and rare distinctions of Australian political leadership in the last generation has been its bipartisan rejection of race as a factor in immigration policy. This has been a triumph of compassion over prejudice, of reason over fear, and of statesmanship over politics. Twenty-two years ago my Party, the Australian Labor Party, disowned its own historic white Australia policy, and the Government led by Harold Holt, to its everlasting credit and honour, abolished the white Australia policy and began to dismantle the administrative machinery of discrimination.This motion is before this House today because that great and rare distinction has been put in jeopardy by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)—the inheritor of the role, but not the mantle, of Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Malcolm Fraser. I say this most sincerely to the Leader of the Opposition: this motion has not been brought forward in any attempt to drive him into the ground. It is not, because if he would retract his position then, as far as this side of the House is concerned, what has happened would be regarded as an aberration and would be forgotten. We would be pleased and proud to re-embrace once again an unqualified bipartisanship on this important issue.So, even in this moment, when a politician sought to divide our country, to divide Australia, Bob Hawke sought to bring us together. He didnt want a Pyrrhic political victory; he wanted a win for the nation, a win that brought us all together again. In this regard, we can thank Bob Hawke not just for the legacy that he has left us but for the lessons that he continues to offer us today about how to move forward as a nation. I offer my condolences to everyone who knew Bob Hawke, to his family in particular, and offer my thanks from a grateful nation.
