Speaker: Mr WATTS (Gellibrand)

name: McBride, Emma, MP
content: Its an honour to speak today to farewell Labor giant Bob Hawke. Today I speak on behalf the Central Coast, one of many communities around the nation that embraced Bob Hawke as their leader. Last night I called my friend Michael Lee, the first member for Dobell and a Keating government minister, for his recollections of Prime Minister Hawke. Michael went way back to 1975, when the Florida Hotel in Terrigal was the backdrop for the Labor national conference. Then ALP President Bob Hawke drew attention for his relaxed attire—patterned speedos—and ended up shirtless in the stocks at Old Sydney Town.On Sunday, 14 December 1986, Prime Minister Hawke officially opened the federally funded Mooney Mooney Creek Bridge, the main road link between Sydney, the Central Coast and the Hunter. Then New South Wales Premier Barry Unsworth quipped that it was a fine example of federalism in action—the federal government raised the money and the state government got to spend it. The replacement of the original Mooney Creek crossing with a four-lane cantilevered concrete structure was deemed an engineering feat at the time. It created a high-speed link between Sydney and Newcastle, opening up the Hunter and Central Coast regions. Thousands of people walked across the bridge that day. Im told it was the biggest bridge opening in New South Wales since the Sydney Harbour Bridge opening. It was a huge celebration, and, as was often his wont, Prime Minister Hawke conducted the band that day. He also recognised the natural beauty of the Central Coast, remarking on that occasion, It was not just one of the most beautiful parts of Australia, but you could go just about anywhere in the world and youre not going to find anything much more beautiful than this.On that day, Prime Minister Hawke also opened the Lake Haven Recreation Centre, built as a community employment project, a job creation program in response to the recession of the early eighties, with the support of the then Wyong Shire Council. Many local kids, like me, grew up playing sport at Lake Haven. The Prime Minister was back on 10 April 1987 to officially open the HopeTown School in Wyong, my home town. I knew the first principal of HopeTown, Elaine Quilty, very well. HopeTown remains a thriving school community, dedicated to serving special education and individual student needs across the Central Coast. On Australia Day 1990, our larrikin Prime Minister arrived by helicopter and was welcomed by over 10,000 people at The Entrance Memorial Park, before hosting a barbecue at The Entrance surf lifesaving club—just another everyday example of his mutual love affair with the Australian people.The higher education reforms of the Hawke government also led to the establishment of the University of Newcastle Ourimbah campus, opened in 1995, the first university campus on the Central Coast of New South Wales.Bob Hawke made many memorable visits to our region on the Central Coast. More importantly, the legacy of his reforms stays with our community. Regional communities around Australia, including the coast, were the main beneficiaries of many of the Hawke governments substantial reforms. His reintroduction of universal public health care in the form of Medicare was one of the most significant Hawke reforms for communities like the coast. As a pharmacist who worked for 20 years in health and 10 years at my local community hospital in Wyong, Ive seen the benefits of this important social reform for our country. Before Medicare, working families on the coast either went without medical care or could be forced into poverty to pay for a hospital stay. Hawkes Medicare removed the financial burden and untethered the imperative to seek health care from the fear that going to hospital could push you towards bankruptcy.Hawkes push to increase the number of children finishing high school was another of his reforms with a far-reaching impact on the Central Coast. As many have already remarked, in 1983 Australias school completion rate was only 30 per cent. It was one of the lowest in the developed world. Eight years later the nations school retention rate had climbed to 70 per cent. This focus on school retention meant that many young people in my community on the Central Coast during the eighties and the early nineties were the first in their families to complete high school, setting them on the path to a better life.I am sure every region around Australia has its own special memories of the peoples Prime Minister. I am honoured to have the opportunity to share just some of the Central Coasts memories here today. In closing, I would like to remember my late nanna Elaine, a life member of the Labor Party. I am wearing nannas 1983 election pin today. She was a great supporter of Bob Hawke and one of the many everyday Australians who had a better life because of him. Thank you, and my condolences to everyone who knew Bob Hawke, from a grateful nation.

name: Georganas, Steve, MP
content: I, too, rise today to speak on the condolence motion for the Hon. Robert James Lee Hawke, one of the greatest prime ministers and Australians that this country has seen. Being a South Australian, I, and many of my colleagues in South Australia, like to claim Bob as one of our own. He was born in Bordertown, a little country town a couple of hundred kilometres out of Adelaide. Bob had some very humble beginnings; he was from a humble background. His father, who was a religious minister in Bordertown, was moved to Perth, and so Bob moved to Perth at a very young age. But, of course, Bordertown hasnt forgotten Bob Hawke. There is a big bust of Bob in the centre of the town, where people are reminded that that was his birthplace. The people of Bordertown are very proud of the former Prime Minister.I was pleased to hear, after Bobs death, the mayor of Bordertown talk about converting Bobs house into a Bob Hawke museum for people to visit. Im not actually sure whether Bordertown is in the member for Barkers electorate—

name: MemberContinuation
content: Mr GEORGANAS: It is. Id like to acknowledge the member for Barker, whos here as well. Im sure he will have more to say on that, Bordertown being in his electorate.Bob was someone who was loved by all Australians. He was a household name well before he entered parliament. I recall my parents, when I was young, talking about the ACTU leader of Australia and the many different battles that were taking place in industrial relations around that time—not only my parents; all their friends and everyone they were connected to knew the name Bob Hawke well before he entered parliament. He was a household name when he did enter parliament. He was someone who had a vision. He had a vision for Australia: to make it fairer and better for working people. We know that he did many things like floating the dollar, to give us a better edge in the global competition taking place, and the formation of APEC. Of course, there was the environment—for example, saving Antarctica and ensuring it was kept pristine. Landcare, which he introduced when he was Prime Minister, looking after the land and, of course, saving the Franklin River were all things under his auspices.He modernised Australia together with Keating. Together they worked in a partnership that was one of the best political partnerships that this country has seen. And, of course, each and every one of us, for a couple of generations now, has been carrying around a little green card in our wallets or back pockets—or its somewhere in a drawer at home—which gives us the ability to visit any doctor and have a great universal healthcare system, which was introduced when he was the Prime Minister in 1983, after he had seen the dismantling of Medibank during Frasers two terms of parliament.We know that Bob had a vision. He had a way of bringing people together. He was able to bring consensus and ensure that he brought people along. It wasnt just about dictating and saying what he wanted through his leadership vision; it was about bringing people together, getting them to understand and leading in a way that ensured that it promoted and gave fairness to all Australians. We saw some great things under his leadership. As I said, he modernised Australia. We ended up with Medicare, which we still revere today. He reformed the industrial relations and of course he also did a lot in immigration and multiculturalism. I recall him visiting the Greek orthodox community in South Australia—a huge event at Olympic Hall—after he had become Prime Minister and the joy on peoples faces at having the Prime Minister of Australia visit this ethnic group that not many people prior had visited. In South Australia we were lucky: we did have Don Dunstan, and Whitlam did attend on a couple of occasions, but you could see Bob that day just walking around in a room of about 800 people, shaking hands, talking to everyone, smiling—and I think he even did a bit of Greek dancing when the festivities began that night.I joined the Labor Party soon after Bob Hawke became the Prime Minister. I was so enthused by Bob that I walked into a party office. I had no connection to the Australian Labor Party in any way. I didnt work for a trade union. In fact, I was driving taxis full time at that time. I had a keen interest in politics and was always on the Labor side of politics, but Bob inspired me so much that I walked into South Terrace and asked to join the Australian Labor Party a couple of days after he was elected Prime Minister. He was the type of person who would enthuse people and bring them along, as I said, when he was coming up with ideas and who wanted to lead the nation.There were some great things that he did. For example, there was assisting in the sanctions that saw apartheid end and the freeing of Nelson Mandela after all those years in jail. It was not just the Australian landscape that he changed but the international landscape as well. He visited Moscow in those years to open up trade and other things. He was someone that had a vision and someone that could see how he could better Australia through policy decision-making not just for the sake of bettering Australia but to ensure that he made it fairer and better for working-class people.We look at superannuation, the wealth creation for working people and something that we didnt have in this nation. Superannuation was for the few privileged prior to Bob Hawke. But he had a vision, together with Keating, to ensure that working people, when they retired, would have some form of wealth savings to be able to live in dignity and to be able to have those things that others had and things they aspired to. I know that, for example, one of the other great things was the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests. I know the former member for Hindmarsh, John Scott, who was the member back then, was lobbying Bob Hawke to look into this area, and we did. He oversaw the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests. It was established back in 1985, I think. It reported with many findings that were implemented and it also looked at the impact of traditional owners and the use of their lands. The commission reported on 5 December.There was the handback of Uluru. We all remember Governor-General Sir Ninian Stephen formally handing back to the Pitjantjatjara traditional owners the deeds and the titles, all under the auspices of one of the greatest Prime Ministers that weve had: Bob Hawke. I had him in the electorate on many occasions, Hindmarsh being a marginal seat—one of the most marginal back in the old seat that I had—and we had one of the largest call centres in the country. It was a Westpac call centre, which was located in Lockleys. Bob had some kind of connection to it after he had retired and had put in the offer to our campaign office to come in and do a walkthrough. There would have been, I think, about 600 people that worked in that call centre. It took us two hours to get out of there. He stopped and spoke to every single person—everyone that he could talk to and shake hands with—and it was not just a gesture but a real conversation with a lot of people, asking them about their work and about how the call centre was going.He was a great bloke. I remember meeting him soon after Id won the seat. Even though hed been to our electorate on a number of occasions, I thought Id go up and say: Hi, Bob. Its Steve Georganas. Im not sure if you remember me. And he said: Of course I remember you. I won the seat for you. This was the type of person he was. He was always joyous. He was always happy to have a chat and always willing to assist and help on campaigns and come out to do street walks with me, and he would be absolutely mobbed when we did. I remember doing a street walk in Jetty Road, Glenelg, where just about every person that was on the street would come up to us to say, Hello, Mr Hawke, and just have a chat. He was a wonderful Prime Minister, a great Australian and a larrikin, and hell be remembered by all and sorely missed by all of us. Our condolences go out to Blanche, his family and his kids.

name: Conroy, Pat, MP
content: I rise to support this condolence motion on the passing of Bob Hawke—larrikin, leader, legend, one of Australias most loved sons, one of Labors most revered figures and one of Australias greatest prime ministers. In fact, he was Labors and Australias greatest peacetime Prime Minister.Bob Hawkes life spanned almost a century. He was born in December 1929, at the start of the Great Depression, an economic catastrophe which inflicted immense hardship on the people of Australia. He died nine decades later, as Australia was enjoying the longest period of uninterrupted growth of any advanced economy, thanks to the reforms he introduced as Prime Minister. Over the span of Bobs life, the country experienced extraordinary events—wars and military conflicts, political crises, and economic booms and busts—and went through tremendous social, technological, cultural and political changes. From his early days as a trade union advocate to his time as Prime Minister and his later years as a Labor stalwart and elder statesman, Bob Hawke was at the centre of so many of these events and was responsible for so many of the changes.The catalogue of his reforms, the list of his achievements, is long and it is far reaching: modernising and internationalising the Australian economy, unlocking its potential and underwriting three decades of prosperity; reorienting the nation from its past as a far-flung part of the British Empire to its future as a confident, outward-looking nation playing a leading role in the Asia-Pacific region; building the Australian social safety net, from Medicare to occupational superannuation and from fair wages and working conditions to accessible higher education; and creating a tolerant, open and diverse society through equal rights for women, support for a multicultural community, human rights and antidiscrimination legislation, and starting the process of reconciliation with Indigenous Australians. Other speakers in this House have reflected on these reforms in more detail. I want to reflect on the fact that many people have been claiming the legacy of Bob Hawke, but most of these reforms were not bipartisan, Im sad to say. Many of them were hard fought and were only secured through great political skill and courage and cemented through winning four elections.Id now like to focus briefly on an aspect of the Hawke legacy which is sometimes overlooked, and thats his role in building an independent Australian defence and strategic posture. Under Bob Hawkes prime ministership, the then defence minister, Kim Beazley, conducted a far-reaching review of Australias defence structure and capabilities. This led to the Hawke governments seminal 1987 white paper entitled The defence of Australia. The white paper laid out a fundamental strategic objective of defence self-reliance within the framework of the ANZUS alliance and Australias regional associations. It also developed the strategic concept of defence in depth and, as Allan Gyngell has written, made the case for a more regionally engaged Australian focus on South-East Asia and the South Pacific. The Hawke government also commissioned the Cooksey review of defence industry, which resulted in reforms to improve Australian industry capabilities and alignment with strategic defence planning. This was seminal work that represented a break with the past in terms of Australias defence planning and was another great legacy of the Hawke government.Another one Id like to mention briefly is his recognition of building political support for economic reforms. Bob understood that to make difficult reforms like dismantling protectionism, restructuring industries and opening up the economy he had to bring the workforce along. Intrinsic to this was his empathy with working people. This allowed him to articulate and explain the economic reforms and to work in partnership with the unions, the workforce and the wider community in implementing and delivering this reform. This was vital. To be fair, and without any disrespect, the stance of the opposition of the day on tariff reforms, on industry restructuring, didnt matter; what mattered was the attitude of the workforce, because ultimately they were the ones who bore the pain of this very necessary structural adjustment. The legacy and the signature approach of Bob Hawke in building consensus and taking the workforce and unions along were essential in carrying forward these reforms.Bob Hawkes presence in modern Australia went beyond the many important achievements and historic reforms. With his gregarious personality, his irreverent wit, his sharp intelligence and his passionate and generous spirit, he embodied and personified the Australian character. Bob has been a huge inspiration in my own political development, as he has been for almost every member on this side of the parliament. I was lucky enough to first meet Bob in 1986 when he came to open the Mooney Mooney Bridge on the Pacific Highway on the New South Wales Central Coast. Anyone who drives the Pacific Motorway knows the Mooney Mooney Bridge, the big dipper. My parents were staunch Labor supporters and took me to the event. I was seven years old. I was standing on the bridge and I was thrilled to get the Prime Ministers autograph.Now that Bob has passed, I wish to extend my condolences to Blanche, Susan, Stephen, Rosslyn, Louis and the rest of Bobs family and friends, and acknowledge the role of the late Hazel Hawke. The nation has lost a leader, a reformer, a statesman and a great citizen. His family have lost a husband, a father, a grandfather and a loved one. We thank them for the support they gave to allow Bob to make such a contribution to the public life of this nation.

Speaker: Mr CONROY (Shortland)

name: Claydon, Sharon, MP
content: Its an extraordinary privilege to join with all of my colleagues today in paying tribute to the life and legacy of the Hon. Robert James Lee Hawke. On 16 May we lost a giant of the labour movement, and all of us on this side of the House felt that pain. He was a bold national reformer and a much-loved Australian.I first became aware of Bob Hawkes presence before he was Prime Minister. My father was at the time president of the ironworkers union in Newcastle, and Bob Hawke was no stranger to the workers of Newcastle and steel industry workers in particular. In those days, the ironworkers union used to invest quite a bit of time and energy into training delegates in the various industries. I remember my father convening a delegates meeting with men—and they were all men—from BHP and Lysaghts and Stewarts & Lloyds and other big companies that no longer exist in Newcastle. Bob Hawke was to spend 10 minutes with the delegates in this training session while he was in Newcastle doing a number of other things in his capacity as President of the ACTU. In typical fashion, that 10 minutes stretched into about an hour and a half by the time he managed to speak to each and every one of those delegates and give them renewed dedication and inspiration for the significance of the labour movement.As my colleague the member for Shortland mentioned, Bob understood, perhaps more than most, the need to build political and community alliances when you were to undergo major social and economic reform in this nation. And that is of course what Bob was always doing. Thats why he always had time for people. Regardless of the position he held, and regardless of any number of minders and advisers around him trying to convince him of the need to keep to certain schedules and times, Bob would always have time to stop and listen. He would listen quite intently to peoples stories—what their passions were and what drove them. And that of course made him such a unique leader in the Australian political landscape.There are a couple of other things Id just like to touch on in the very limited time available tonight—the things that I grew to really love about Bob Hawke. He was a risk taker, and he knew precisely the times when he had to take those big risks. I was really privileged not that long ago to spend some time with Mr Bill Bowtell, who was at one time a health adviser to Neal Blewett in the Hawke government. He talked to me about how they first dealt with the HIV/AIDS epidemic as it was unfolding in Australia, when we knew very little about this virus. He went to then Prime Minister Bob Hawke and said: You know, Im going to need your permission to offend probably every single group in Australia and take on every vested interest. Im going to need to be able to talk about IV drug use, prostitution, anal sex, gay/lesbian culture, and we need to tackle this front on. Bob, to his great credit—understanding full well in the 1980s that that meant taking on the church, the police, the medical profession and indeed the media—knew what was right and he had the courage to take the risk and say: This is a public health epidemic. Thats what we need to do. And he gave his health minister and advisers licence to then lead the world in dealing with what was an unbelievable epidemic at the time. Its hard to imagine whether a Prime Minister would have had the courage today to do that.I would also like to acknowledge with thanks Bobs total rejection of racism and prejudice in this nation. That is something that lives with me and with, I know, so many members—especially on this side of the House but certainly not exclusively. I was a young anthropologist working in the field when Bob was Prime Minister and remember his instrumental commitment to redressing the relationship that existed with First Nations people and subsequent settlers in this nation. Many, many years ago—some 30 years ago now—we had the first Barunga Statement, which we have here in parliament hanging near the Members Hall. It was such a radical document at the time, yet today we have failed to deliver consistently on the requests of that Barunga Statement. Along with Senators Pat Dodson and Malarndirri McCarthy, Linda Burney, Bill Shorten and the member for Brand, last year I attended the Barunga Festival, 30 years after the statement was presented to Bob Hawke. It was sad that the promise of a treaty all those decades ago remains elusive in Australia. We have failed to really come to terms with how we now seek redress to the 230-year colonial relationship. But the lesson I took from that Barunga Festival last year, 30 years down the track, and from Bobs passing on 16 May is the need to redouble our efforts now. It is incumbent on all of us who sit in this chamber to do everything we can to realise his commitments and his honours and his promises to First Nations people.Id finally like to acknowledge Bobs family. I had the pleasure of working alongside Steve Hawke over a number of years in Fitzroy Crossing. Steves mum and Bobs first wife, Hazel, was a frequent visitor to Fitzroy Crossing too. I send my sincere condolences to Steve, to Ros, to Sue, who went on to do such magnificent work with Hazel around dementia later on, and of course to Bobs later life companion, Blanche.Thank you, Bob, for your vision, for your courage, for your compassion, for your steadfast commitment to bringing Australians together, for always saying no to racism and division and for the leadership role you took in reforming Australia to ensure we were a better nation. We know that you loved Australia, and we certainly loved you too. Vale Bob Hawke.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Ms CLAYDON (Newcastle)

name: Rowland, Michelle, MP
content: I joined the Labor Party in early 1990, around the time of the federal election that year. It was the first time I had voted, and I enthusiastically voted for the sitting Labor member for Greenway in order for Bob Hawke to remain Prime Minister. It was of course Bob Hawkes fourth and final election victory, and he would go out undefeated at the polls.My greatest appreciation of Bob Hawke is that he was the ultimate marginal seat campaigner—the seats and the messaging in elections where they are won and lost. Dont get me wrong: he would feel just at home in a safe seat held by any party or any individual. But something I maintain that only those of us who have to fight for every vote to win their seat to get here and to stay here truly understand is that its about the constant effort to build and strengthen relationships with people, to not take anyone for granted and to prove yourself with everyone. How do you do that these days, to connect with 100,000 voters who live in an electorate like mine in Greenway, who are so diverse in every aspect, from age to ethnic background, to religion, to income? Ive come to appreciate more than ever in reflecting on Bob Hawke that how you engage with people can be just as important and sometimes more relevant in the eyes of voters than your partys actual policies. For Bob Hawke it was always about relationships. The lesson of Bob Hawke is that he was so approachable. He loved meeting people. He was authentic. He didnt talk down to people, but he didnt dumb himself down either. He was a man of incredible intellect and status but, rather than begrudge him because of it, Australians respected him because of it.People I know who were around him during government stressed his incredible work ethic. By the time of the 1990 election he was around 60 years old, but he was incredibly fit and motivated and his campaign schedule was punishing. And, as he got older, he never stopped campaigning for the Labor Party, for Labor candidates and for sitting Labor MPs. In 2010, when I was running for the first time, he came out to Blacktown and did a walk through at Westpoint Shopping Centre, Blacktown. Just like everyone else has said in their remarks, he was utterly mobbed by everyone. It didnt matter their age or their background, everyone wanted a piece of him. It was like they were touching someone holy. He never lost that aura, and he was so generous in being ready to campaign for the Labor cause.In 2013, when it was hard to find friends, he still came out to Blacktown and, speaking to Labor supporters and motivating them just before campaign day, he said something I will never forget. He rattled off all the arguments he knew our opponents would make going into that election and he encouraged everyone to arm themselves with the facts: Here are the facts about the Labor mission and what Labor has done to bring Australia to this point of its economic prosperity. This was well before fake news was a thing. He told everyone to arm themselves with the facts.Bob Hawke had every attribute to ensure that over time he set the standard. Indeed, in 1980, the Labor campaign slogan was Raise the Standard. This was an election that Labor did not win—did very well but did not win—and it was the election where he entered parliament. I have a poster that takes pride of place in my office featuring Bob Hawke with Lionel Bowen, Bill Hayden and Neville Wran—giants of the labour movement. I had to remind myself that, although he was being featured heavily in this campaign, he was actually entering parliament for the first time. How unprecedented was that?This guy was actually a candidate and he was being featured alongside the great leaders of the Labor Party. I never really appreciated what raise the standard meant until I thought about how this was about taking Australia and saying: We are a very lucky country, but we need to make ourselves better. Australia is good, but we need to be making ourselves better.In conclusion, we as Labor people are often approached by punters who will make the remark that Labor have never had a leader since like Bob Hawke and that we will never have the kind of messiah quality that Bob Hawke had again. If we are going to just accept that as a fact then the Labor mission is hollow. I know what Bob Hawke would have said, just as Im sure you do, Madam Deputy Speaker Claydon. Instead of just accepting that as fact, he would be turning on the three lessons I have outlined here: the importance of connecting with everyone, the importance of arming yourself with the facts to have quality debate on the issues that matter and, just as Bob Hawke said, the importance for us in Labor to always be raising the standard, to never accept the status quo and to never accept that near enough is good enough. They are the lessons that I take from Bob Hawke. Im grateful, just as I know all of us in Labor are, for his life and his service to our country and to our movement.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Ms ROWLAND (Greenway)

name: Freelander, Mike, MP
content: I have a very personal reason to revere the memory of Bob Hawke. Bob and his deputy, Paul Keating, in their governments, provided the framework for the modern, multicultural and dynamic society we have today. Bob Hawkes achievements were many. My colleagues have spoken of his many, many achievements and the many things he provided for Australian society to make it a better place. Environmental reforms, education reforms and the concept of the accord and a social wage were very, very important. The Hawke team had many people of high achievement and high ability, but Hawke brought them all together and allowed each to use their skills for the benefit of all Australians. As weve heard on numerous occasions, Bob Hawke had charm, sex appeal and charisma. Above all else, however, he had a huge intellect and huge courage.I started my private paediatric practice in February 1984, the same month and year that Medicare was introduced to the Australian public. I have been forever grateful. Id seen, as a medical student, resident, registrar and fellow, how many people struggled to access health care, particularly high-level care, and how many families feared health challenges, not because of the physical effects but because of the financial challenges. Inability to pay healthcare costs was a common cause of bankruptcy and family breakdown. The reintroduction of a universal health insurance scheme dramatically changed access to health care for millions of Australians. I, more than many in this place, have had a very personal reason to be grateful. Medicare formed the backbone of my medical career for over 30 years.Bob Hawkes introduction of Medicare was a huge social change, but it wasnt easy. Some on the other side are very fond of trying to rewrite history about this. I remember every day of that campaign. I remember the bitterness. I remember the huge intimidation that was attempted by conservative politicians and conservative doctors. Indeed, my own organisation, the AMA, of which Ive been a member for over 40 years, under Bruce Shepherd fought tooth and nail, with the connivance of conservative politicians, to stop the introduction of the universal healthcare scheme that we are so grateful for today.I remember that time very, very well. Ever since, Ive been grateful for Bob Hawkes courage. And, remember, it took a lot of courage. This was a time of financial instability. The Australian economy was stressed. There were lots of other stresses. But Bob Hawke stood firm. It was on the back of a lot of work by people like Ralph Willis and Neal Blewett and by the original proponents of a universal healthcare scheme, such as Dick Scott and John Deeble. But it required enormous courage to push this through, and what a benefit it has been. It has kept our healthcare costs much lower than in comparable developed countries. It has provided access, and equitable access, to health care for so many millions of people. Ive been forever grateful because it provided me with a very stable and very financially successful private practice in paediatrics. We should also remember the role of Bill Hayden, Bob Hawkes predecessor as the leader of the parliamentary Labor Party for his role in this. I want to make the point very strongly, though, that it took a lot of courage on the part of Bob Hawke. It wouldve been so easy for him to back down under that pressure. We should all be so grateful for that. I remember the intimidation and I remember how much pressure was put on Hawke and his government to back down.Id also like to mention—it has been mentioned previously—the role that Bob Hawke and Neal Blewett had in combating HIV. 1984 was also the time when the HIV virus was first beginning to be described. It took a lot of courage to run that dramatically successful campaign of HIV education in the eighties that really saved the lives of many Australians. We should also be very grateful for that.I dont want to take any longer, but I remember Bob Hawke so fondly not only for Medicare but for his other innovative health policies. Others have spoken so much on his other achievements. Id like to offer my personal condolences to his wife, Blanche, and his family, including his children and grandchildren. Its been a great privilege for me to speak today on the condolence motion for Bob Hawke, a great Australian. Thank you.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Dr FREELANDER (Macarthur)

name: Gorman, Patrick, MP
content: Robert James Lee Hawke was Prime Minister for the first seven years of my life. He was just 11 days into his second term when I was born. I am so grateful to have grown up in Bob Hawkes Australia. Indeed, I grew up in Fremantle, which itself was transformed by the hosting of the Americas Cup in 1987.Bob Hawke and Labors winning of the 1984 election was in large part due to Medicare. Im so thankful that they did. It was that universal health system that Bob Hawke built that helped me, as an asthmatic child, be healthy, fit and here today. Equally, Medicare allowed my parents—both teachers on average wages—to worry about my health, not their bank balance.Though Bob was born in South Australia to Clem and Ellie, its no surprise that Western Australians claim Bob as one of their favourite sons. Bob spent his formative years in West Leederville, then in the electorate of Fremantle and held by his hero, John Curtin. He attended Perth Modern School in the middle of World War II. Its no surprise that there he enrolled in army cadets. Indeed, the community of Perth Modern remembers his contribution at that time in digging trenches at the school as part of that cadet training. Later he enjoyed the wonders of university life at the University of Western Australia. We thank Perth Modern School and the University of Western Australia for their contribution to giving us that great Labor Prime Minister. Bob became guild president of the University of Western Australia in 1951. I know that because every guild president from the University of Western Australia I have ever met tells you very proudly, You know, Bob Hawke was guild president—wink, wink, nudge, nudge.In 1953 he graduated, and in 1953 his uncle Bert Hawke became Labor Premier of Western Australia. Bert Hawkes compassion for Aboriginal Western Australians and his commitment to raising school leaving ages and to the practical alleviation of poverty was clearly an inspiration to his nephew. It was also on the streets of Perth where Bob crashed his Panther motorcycle. The accident left him drifting between life and death. His parents worried they would lose another son. Western Australia did help form the Prime Minister that we have been celebrating in this place today. Western Australia also gave him the much-loved Hazel and helped bring into the world his children. I think its been great to hear the tributes to Hazel as well today.As union leader and then president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, he brought people together. He reformed the Labor movement. As Western Australians, we loved him, and we showed that at the 1983 election. That adoration shone through. He won eight out of 11 seats in Western Australia, something the Western Australian branch of the Labor Party could only dream of today. There was an average swing of almost nine per cent across the state. It was at that election that Labor regained the seat of Perth, which we have now held for the last 35 or so years. On election night, when the results came in, it became apparent that the Hawke government had not just won but had won in a landslide, with 24 seats gained—the largest defeat of a sitting government in more than 30 years. Because of that election, more children than ever finished their schooling, health care was finally accessible to all and the nation benefited from both real and social wage increases. Womens rights, economic participation, reconciliation with our First Peoples, regional economic engagement and environmental protection—weve spent the day celebrating all of those achievements. His 1983 campaign slogan, Bringing Australia together, defined his character and the entire time he served as Prime Minister.After his time as Prime Minister, he continued to campaign. He loved campaigning and he loved advocating the cause of Labor. I saw that up close in March 2017 as campaign director for the WA Labor Party. Five days out from the election, Bob was our final secret weapon. We had him come to endorse Mark McGowan at the Perth Town Hall, and he did so. I think he was really there to endorse Bob Hawke, but nonetheless he did help us with a historic election win. The night before, I had the privilege of dining with him; Mark McGowan; my wife, Jess; and the members for Brand, Burt and Fremantle amongst others at the Kent Street Deli in Rockingham. Im almost certain that was the only time Bob would have ever gone to the Kent Street Deli in Rockingham. It was a great night. He was in great spirits, telling jokes I could not repeat in this place or anywhere, and also complaining that we hadnt given him enough campaigning to do. I want to thank Gary Gray for organising that dinner. That was my last meaningful engagement with Bob, and Im very grateful for that opportunity.I want to commend the Prime Minister for his announcement of the scholarship to honour the Hawke legacy. I think thats a really touching and meaningful announcement that he made this morning. In the same vein, I want to note the commitment that next year in Subiaco, in Western Australia, Bob Hawke College will open. Many young Australians from my electorate will complete their schooling years at Bob Hawke College. It wont be just a great school; it will carry on Bobs legacy. It will carry on his belief that education really can transform a childs future.I want to pass on my sincerest condolences to Blanche, the Hawke family, all of Bobs former staff, Jill Saunders and everyone in Australia who loved him and had a relationship with him, whether they knew him or not. In solidarity forever, vale Bob Hawke.
subdebateinfo: Hawke, Hon. Robert James Lee (Bob), AC
Speaker: Mr GORMAN (Perth)

name: Ryan, Joanne, MP
content: Bob Hawke: a political giant, a great union man, a great Labor man, a great Australian, a great Prime Minister. I join today with my parliamentary colleagues to mourn the loss and celebrate the life and contributions of Bob Hawke in this place and beyond these walls. Through his service, his great friendship with Paul Keating and his belief in his gifted cabinet, Bob Hawke created modern Australia. We are all indebted to his leadership for the social and economic progress that he led as our 23rd Prime Minister. Weve heard today the list of the social, environmental and economic policies that are now accepted practice. We cant imagine Australia without them. Ill not go on and list them.Bob Hawke steered our country through dramatic change, and it is this that is remarkable. He did it with an understanding of leadership. He proudly served our nation with courage and conviction, as has been attested to today, but for me what was most important was his understanding of change and of what needed to be done to ensure change was not rejected by the Australian people but embraced. He allowed his authority to grow in government. He knew that change was dramatic. He knew that if fear of change took over he would not be able to deliver. He wove, therefore, a story of hope; he seduced us. As a result, people let him lead. We let him dream and we let him deliver. He earned the trust of the Australian people and, in turn, implemented change to progress their interests. He let the people into his thinking. He used his wit. He made us laugh. He and Keating took Australianness into this chamber. They were irreverent. Hawke took this irreverence, his larrikinism, to the world stage unashamedly, and we loved it.I grew up in Victoria under Liberal governments. My first political memory was the sacking of Gough Whitlam, so before Bob Hawke Id never really seen consciously a federal Labor government. I hadnt seen a state Labor government. In my early 20s I voted for Barry Jones in the seat that I now proudly represent, and of course he went into Bob Hawkes cabinet. It was the first time in my short voting record that my vote was for the party that would ultimately form government—a Hawke government. As a student studying at The University of Melbourne, I joined thousands of fellow students in protesting against the Fraser government and its intent that would see the most vulnerable in our community suffer. In those protests we played our small part in delivering the Hawke government. When I was thinking about this yesterday, I noted that our former Prime Minister Julia Gillard was marching in the streets of Adelaide at the same time. Of course, Julia went on to become the member for Lalor and a great prime minister.That Hawke government, under Bobs urging, wisely built social policy to support people while he asked them to trust his government to make radical economic change. His optimism about who we were and who we could be shaped a generation. He taught us that we were a country where by working together we could overcome intransigence and we could become a country less judgemental and more forgiving and embracing, where individual contributions would be valued and celebrated, where we were proud of our unique voice, our unique vision and our unique unfinished story, and we celebrated that in the Australian film industry at the time. He taught us that we could see reconciliation with our First Peoples on the horizon, and all we had to do was reach for it. Our larrikin PM who put aside our old judgemental selves and our hypercritical past and embraced our own Australianness defined us as a nation. We wanted to be better and we wanted to do better.Theres a saying in drama and in writing: dont tell them; show them. Thats what Bob did. He showed us what pride looked like, what love for country looked like and what a fair society looked like. Bob leaves our country and the Australian Labor Party a formidable legacy to defend and live up to, and I will join my colleagues every day to do that. He made us proud to be ourselves. He made us proud of our achievements. He made us feel like winners. From the song he loved to sing come the lines:We have laid the wide foundations, built it skyward stone by stoneIt is ours, not to slave in, but to master and to ownBob taught us how to live this.My deepest condolences and thanks go to Bobs family for sharing him with us. And, please, know that fewer children lived in poverty because of Bob, more children got opportunity because of Bob, swathes of our environment are still protected because of Bob and families no longer had to make a monetary choice to see a doctor because of Bob. Vale Bob, from a grateful Australia. Solidarity forever.

Speaker: Ms RYAN (Lalor—Opposition Whip)

name: Chesters, Lisa, MP
content: No-one could sing Solidarity Forever like Bob Hawke. Many of us on this side of the chamber can remember this from going to an ACTU event or a Labor event. It didnt matter who spoke that night or that day. In the moment when Bob stood up and sang Solidarity Forever, he was the star of the show. There was an ACTU dinner one year where we recognised Bill Kelty for his fantastic contribution. He spoke, as Bill does, for quite some time about the great challenge for the labour movement and the great challenge for Labor. Paul Keating also spoke and, again, spoke for a very long time, as Paul is known to do, about the great challenge for the labour movement and the great challenge for Labor. Like always, it was Bob who stole the show with the way he sang Solidarity Forever, the way it lifts the room up and the way in which it reminded all of us of the hope, the aspiration and the solidarity that he had and lived each and every day of his life.Bob, as we have heard today, influenced many, particularly on my side of politics. He had a way of connecting with people that really made them feel included and inspired. My electorate of Bendigo had the great privilege and pleasure to meet with Bob on many occasions. When Bob became Prime Minister, John Brumby was the federal member for Bendigo. He held the seat for a number of years. Back then and still today, Bendigo is considered a marginal seat. Bob visited Bendigo many times. On his passing during the election campaign, I was stopped many times at early voting centres with people telling me their story of Bob, such as Bob walking down Hargreaves Mall and just stopping to have a yarn and chat. People would be saying: My God, there goes Bob Hawke. He just spoke to me. Bob Hawke spoke to me. It would be talked about for weeks on end when he visited.Fabian Reid, the former chief of staff to John Brumby, refers to Bob Hawkes visits to Bendigo as being like a visit from a rock star. He said they just had to mention it to one person and, before you knew it, thousands knew about it. He recalled ALP members falling over themselves to host events at their own houses and at their own workplaces. From the moment they heard that Bob was coming to town, it was hard to turn people away and it was hard to say no, because everybody wanted to meet Bob and to host Bob. Fundraisers that were sometimes supposed to be small gatherings—you might invite local businesses along or local health and community leaders along—turned into bigger events once you mentioned that Bob Hawke was coming. Fabian recalled one fundraiser where they were struggling to get numbers. It was close to the election. Bob agreed to come, and it sold out within minutes. Its that kind of influence that he had, particularly in regional communities.He visited Bendigo on a number of occasions. He drew big crowds, but he also went to our smaller towns in the region. He didnt miss an opportunity to engage with everyone. He spent time in Maldon, and he spent time in Castlemaine. When the seat went north to what we would call Tiger country, he also ventured north. His ability to connect with people in the regions was just as strong. Even though our primary vote in some of these areas was as little as 20 per cent, it was like they forgot for a moment that they might not have been Labor inclined. That was because Bob was in town. They really connected with his values, with his ideas and with him because he was Prime Minister. It is has often been reflected in Bendigo that we havent had a Prime Minister since Bob Hawke spending so much time in our electorate. He really understood the regions and spent the time there. John Brumby would probably say that it was because he was a great advocate. But it was more the fact that Bob really understood that if you really want to represent the people you need to know the people and you need to be on the ground.During his prime ministership, as we know, a lot of his key reforms really did help the people of my electorate. Today were going through our own Medicare crisis. The doctors, once again, have closed their books. We have a shortage of GPs. Thats largely because of what is happening to Medicare and Medicare payments. Theyre losing their bulk-billing incentives because Bendigo has been removed from the regional districts of workforce shortage list, and having to charge gap fees means they lose bulk-billing payments that are incurred with that. People are paying more and more today than they ever have to access GP services—if they can get into a GP. With the passing of Bob, were reminded that we need to continue the campaign at a local level to ensure that Medicare survives, that we see the investment thats required to ensure that, regardless of where they live, no kid, no grandparent, no pensioner, no worker is denied access to a GP when they need one.I can remember one person telling me a story, and he said: Look, it mustve been after he was no longer Prime Minister, because Bob still made trips to Bendigo to support candidates. We were walking down the street and we were having a bit of a party, and we said: Oi, Bob! You want a beer? And he said, Yes, Id love one mate! This person was reflecting on it, saying, It mustve been after he was Prime Minister, because Im pretty sure he didnt drink while he was Prime Minister. I think that was the strength of Bob: he continued to campaign in the same way after he was no longer Prime Minister as he did before he was Prime Minister and while he was Prime Minister.He had some great advice for all of us new MPs in 2013. Many of my colleagues here will remember the dinner we had where we all got the opportunity to meet Bob. I was really keen to talk to Bob about apartheid, his meeting Nelson Mandela and the other great things he had done in his career. The first thing he said to me was: Bendigo; thats a tough seat for us. Are you doing your street stalls? Doorknockings important. He wanted to make sure that I was doing the work on the ground that I needed to do to continue to be the federal member for Bendigo. All politics is local, he said. Thats something that John Brumby also said to me, after I was preselected. And he said, Theyre not my words, theyre Bobs words. So Bob has continued to have an influence on the generations of candidates that have come through since.Another person who wanted to share their story about Bob talked about the time when he tried to come to Bendigo—well, he did come to Bendigo, but he was delayed because of a broken-down tram. He was stuck for two hours. There was this big crowd waiting for Bob, but people didnt disappear; the crowd just kept growing. Hes going to get here. Hell be here. The story in the media ended up being about Bob Hawke and the broken-down tram, telling the story about why he was late. But the real story shouldve been that an event that was supposed to have 50 people ended up having 500 people because during the two-hour delay more people found out he was on his way.One of the big things that many of us also reflected on, particularly people of my generation—I confess that I just fit into gen Y—is that Bob Hawke is the first Prime Minister we can remember as kids. We fondly remember the leadership he took around Tiananmen Square as part of those early political memories that kids have. To be at primary school, to be at secondary school and to see the leadership that he took on a lot of social reforms, those are things you value and learn from, as children and as young adults, and reflect upon later in life. He brought so much of value to the role of Prime Minister and to our country. He didnt compromise on racism, he didnt compromise on equality, and he consistently campaigned to ensure that was at the forefront of all he did—even when it was considered unpopular.Finally, Id like to make a few remarks on his role in the great trade union movement. It is a hard role to be the secretary, to be the president, to be an official of the ACTU at any time—just ask todays leaders—particularly when you have a dogged government that is going after your ability to organise and your ability to represent workers. But he stood up to that and always spoke to the value of representation, and to the value of workers having a say in their workplace, to justice and fairness.Those skills that he had in the ACTU really saw the elevation of the union movement and of the ACTU. He is, and continues to be, a much-loved figure of the union movement because he managed to do what so many others before and after have not been able to do: be a true Labor leader and a Labor union leader, bring those values of unionism into this place and encourage all Australians to embrace them. Never did he waver from that conviction. Never did he say or believe or advocate that union was a dirty word, that we needed to look at the role that unions played in modern Australia. And we all remember one of the first acts he did as Prime Minister was to bring unions and industry together.Now, there are mixed views about the role of the accord and what that did for working people in Australia. There are some people in the union movement who said that unions became lazy once the accord came in. Maybe it wasnt the best strategic move. But what I recall, and what a lot of workers recall, is that it gave them a decent wage. It give working people—cleaners, security guards, people in award based industries—a decent pay and it gave them regular pay rises and the opportunity to start to organise and to build respect in their workplace.He has so many lasting values and legacies that all of us will remember, but, for the people of Bendigo, its his character that people reflect on the most: the fact that he made politics and parliament inclusive; the fact that he was willing to walk down the mall, have a chat, share a story; the fact that he could inspire people just by a conversation. He took the time to go to Maldon. He took the time to go to Castlemaine. Like no other Prime Minister before and after, he really did speak up and care for people in the regions, particularly the people in Bendigo.

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS (Bendigo)

name: Wilson, Josh, MP
content: Im very glad to have the opportunity to reflect with gratitude and celebration on the life of Bob Hawke. He was without doubt one of the great Australian Prime Ministers and the greatest in my lifetime. He was a distinctively Labor Prime Minister, which means he knew the foundational importance of the things we share: fair pay and working conditions, high-quality public health and education, a comprehensive social safety net, the beauty and biodiversity of our environment, and our egalitarian and multicultural way of life.I was in year 7 at South Terrace Primary School in Freo when the Hawke government was elected, and at the end of that year Australia won the Americas Cup, which was particularly momentous for my home town of Fremantle. 1983 was in many ways the birth of my political consciousness. The Hawke government showed me and many others what could be achieved through politics and what a difference a good government could make.Today in this debate weve been reminded of the staggering list of reforms delivered by Bob Hawke as Prime Minister. If I had to choose a policy to single out, it would be the family allowance reforms that provided better support for low-income and single-parent households, and in so doing made an enormous difference to millions of families—including mine. In the period 1980 to 1994, financial assistance for low-income families in Australia increased from being 60 per cent of the OECD average in 1980 to being 140 per cent of the OECD average in 1994. That is a massive leap, and I have no doubt that other transformative achievements like those in the area of educational opportunity and attainment were to some degree built on the family allowance reforms.Above all else, Bob Hawke and the government he led turned the wheel when it came to inequality and disadvantage in this country. He turned the wheel through the architecture of an inclusive economy and through massive improvements in our social compact, in public health, in education and in welfare support. It is well past time for us all to put our shoulder to that wheel again.I only met Bob Hawke a few times, but he was one of those people who communicated his nature and his temperament in that first contact. He was fundamentally affable and generous, good natured and good humoured. He looked you in the eye, he called you by your name and he grinned. I can remember that in the 2007 election campaign we organised a walk-through of the Phoenix Shopping Centre in the suburb of Spearwood for Bob and the then candidate for Fremantle, Melissa Parke. On the day the time was pushed back to be mid-morning. It was a weekday. We were concerned that there wouldnt be much of a crowd and it might not do justice to his time and effort. Someone suggested to Bob that perhaps we could just do a photo and have a coffee in a local coffee shop. But, characteristically, he was having none of that. He insisted that we go through the shopping centre. Like the storm that he was, he left us all in his wake. He reached out and shook hands with every person in the place. There seemed to be a kind of electric charge that drew people into his aura and spun them off to one side as he passed through. I remember a young bloke, slightly dazzled, took me by the arm and said, Who was that? He didnt know it, but he had just had the Bob Hawke experience.In 2017, before the WA state election, Bob came across to campaign with Mark McGowan, as the member for Perth mentioned earlier. A dinner was organised in Rockingham. I was very fortunate to attend with the member for Brand, among others. That night Bob told one of the jokes that he is famous for. Three people from different nations—a Frenchman, a Pom and an Australian, of course—are captured by a local tribe, which intends to punish their trespass with death. The head of the tribe offers the captives a choice between taking matters into their own hands or being put to a ritual death that will culminate in their skin being made into a canoe. In telling the joke Bob did the accents, which, you will all be glad to know, Im not going to do. The French bloke and the Englishman, one after the other, asked for a knife and proceeded to do the deed after expressing some noble sentiments—God save the Queen; vive la France and so on. When it gets to the Australians turn, he asks for a fork. He proceeds to prod himself up and down methodically, all over his body. Then he says, So much for your bloody canoe!Everyone laughed. A lot of the people there had heard that joke a few times from Bob. They still laughed. Bob himself laughed, before he had finished telling the joke and once he had finished telling the joke. One thing we know about Bob Hawke is that he loved to share his voice in joy and good humour and camaraderie. But he also had the courage to raise his voice and make an argument to make some noise in the cause of change, in the cause of difficult but necessary reform, in the cause of social and economic justice. Those twin capacities to bond and lift the spirits of his fellow Australians on the one hand and to lead and change for the better the way we live together in this country on the other make him remarkable.On behalf of the Fremantle community, I offer sincere condolences to Blanche and Bobs family and to his many, many friends. As others have described so well in this debate, the legacy of the Hawke government reaches deep and wide into Australian life today. Its a legacy that has shaped and should continue to shape contemporary Australia, but the ripples have already travelled over a lot of water by now. The passing of Bob Hawke is an opportunity for us to remember that for us to be the custodians of his legacy we must not shirk the hard yakka of fighting for change, for building consensus and for making it last.

Speaker: Mr JOSH WILSON (Fremantle)

name: Butler, Terri, MP
content: Its a real pleasure to rise in this debate to join in the celebration of the life of one of Australias greatest ever prime ministers, Bob Hawke. To Bobs family and Blanche, we feel Bobs loss as a party, as a nation and as a people. I would like to add my condolences and those of my husband, Troy, to the family and friends of Bob Hawke. We know he is so sadly missed and we offer our sincerest condolences. I extend those also on behalf of the people of Griffith.Bobs capacity to connect with and to deliver for Australians was unrivalled. He was a Rhodes scholar, a punter, a beer-sculling intellectual, a union leader, a friend of business and workers, a Prime Minister and a great economic and social policy architect. He shaped much of modern Australia. He was a great egalitarian, and he imbued these values into the Australian psyche more than any other political leader. He knew the value of listening to Australians, respecting their views and bringing them along on the reform journey that is the foundation of Australias amazing 28 years of continuous economic growth. Its economic growth based on fairness. Its lifted Australian living standards to among the highest in the world.Bob knew the economy must work first and foremost for Australian families. High-paying jobs, better skills and highly educated, healthy and prosperous Australian families were at the forefront of an unprecedented period of change in the international economy. The developed economies of the world were going through a period that nobody really knew how to deal with—that was, stagflation. We had high inflation and high unemployment. Conservative governments around the world sought to deal with that through deregulation and union busting. But not Bob. Bob saw an opportunity for collaboration with the union movement. Thats how we got the Prices and Incomes Accord. It was that economic foresight and willingness to work together in a consensus-building way—not to union bust and deregulate but to come up with the Prices and Incomes Accord—that really broke the back of inflation in this country, the major pressing economic challenge of the early 1980s and beyond. He did that because he knew the importance of strong wages and fair industrial laws in building the economic success of our nation.More importantly, I think, the lesson from the Hawke and Keating era, from all sides of politics, was that you dont just magically stumble across economic success as a nation. Opening our economy up to the world, delivering Medicare, lifting school retention rates, boosting higher education access and success rates, skilling our next generation for trades linked to jobs in our economy, giving people dignity in retirement through our world-class retirement income system—all of these elements were crucial to our success as a nation. They are all part of the Hawke-Keating economic legacy and Australias economic architecture, which we should never forget and we should never allow to be eroded.I want to mention Bobs impact in my home state of Queensland and on the people of Griffith, because it was tremendous. Prior to his prime ministership, only about 40 per cent of the Queenslanders completed year 12 but, by the end of his prime ministership, it was up to 85 per cent of Queenslanders finishing school. Im in that statistic. My parents went to grade 10, as was very common at the time. It was rare in my home town of Cairns to go past grade 10. But one generation later, my sister and I both finished grade 12 and we both went to university. It was a quantum leap in one generation and it was because of Labors work in education under Bob Hawke.Bob Hawke was also one of the great environmental reformers of our nations history. He knew there was no point in being a voice from the sidelines on the environment; you had to win government to protect it, and thats exactly what he did. He protected Kakadu and the Tasmanian wilderness as well. He saved the Franklin River from damming. He protected Antarctica, still the most significant environmental conservation action in the worlds history. Its an incredible thing to have achieved. But I want to mention the World Heritage listing of the wet tropics. I was born in Cairns. My parents were born in Cairns. I and my family have a long history in Far North Queensland. As a child, one of my first memories of politics was how controversial that World Heritage listing of the wet tropics was. It seems like a no-brainer today but it was incredibly controversial. My uncle Jim worked in the sawmill at Ravenshoe, which was affected by the wet tropics World Heritage listing. I remember the pain that that community went through.My earliest memory of Bob Hawke was of course the joyous memory of our Prime Minister being so engaged in our national sporting events. As a kid, you care so much about the fact that we won the Americas Cup; it is such a big memory. But probably my second memory of him is of my aunt throwing a phone brick at the TV every time he came on, because she lived in Ravenshoe and logging was being shut down as a consequence of the World Heritage listing. They were hurt. Economic reform is not easy; environmental reform is not easy. But for me and countless people around the world, the World Heritage listing of that amazing wet tropics area, including the Daintree and all the way down almost to Townsville—its a massive area of Queensland—is so important for the preservation of those World Heritage values. In fact, the first protest I ever attended, I was a kid. The first protest I ever attended as a child was to protest against a development planned for that World Heritage area. I wish I could do justice to the significance of the work that Bob Hawke did to protect the natural environment for the benefit of Australians and for the benefit of the world. He really was a great Australian and a great conservationist.Bob Hawke—Hawkie—was one of the greatest reformers in our history, along with Paul Keating and his predecessor Gough Whitlam. Those Labor prime ministers who came after them were fortunate to have them as people to look up to. I know that Prime Minister Rudd and Prime Minister Gillard drew so much from the legacy of Bob Hawke and Paul Keating. There was something about Bob, wasnt there? There was something so Australian. He brought us together as a nation. Our country—our small but prosperous and brave country—became the optimistic, forward-thinking, modern nation that it is now because of the work that Bob did during his prime ministership. He is so sorely missed, because he was a proud Australian who did Australia proud. He will be missed. Hes been honoured by the contributions that have been made today. Well never forget his contribution or his memory. Cheers, Hawkie.

Speaker: Ms BUTLER (Griffith)

name: King, Madeleine, MP
content: Western Australia has created great things. Our nations greatest Prime Minister, John Curtin, while born in Victoria, like many others sought work and prosperity in WA and, as the member for Fremantle, he led this nation through its darkest days in World War II. John Curtin remains the only Prime Minister to represent a Western Australian constituency. Our nations greatest peacetime Prime Minister, Robert James Lee Hawke, while born in South Australia and holding a Victorian seat, was raised and spent his formative years in Western Australia. Western Australians can lay some very significant claim to these extraordinary Australian Labor leaders and our greatest prime ministers, John Curtin and Bob Hawke.But, today, we pay tribute to Bob Hawke. And, today, we have heard remarkable tributes in this place to a truly great Australian who indeed helped build this place and who made an unrivalled contribution to make Australia the remarkable nation that it is. Bobs life was that of a true federalist—born in South Australia, raised and educated in Western Australia, built a career in Victoria and here in the ACT and retiring, for the most part, in Sydney, New South Wales.Many have talked about his stellar achievements and his remarkable legacy that changed Australia for the better. Today, Id like to reflect on the important part Western Australia played in the life of perhaps our last Western Australian Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. He went to school at West Leederville Primary School, before going to Perth Modern School. From Perth Mod, he went to the University of Western Australia. My mum, Diana Morris, who was then Diana Pizer, grew up in the same area of Perth, in West Perth. Im pleased to say that Mum is here today in the gallery, as it happens. They were of similar age, although Bob was a bit older. Bob went to the selective Perth Modern School through the granting of a scholarship and Mum went to a school nearby, Thomas Street State School, also in West Perth.When Bob Hawke became Prime Minister, I was about 10 and Mum would mention that she used to go on youth camps with Bob and other teenagers in the Congregational Youth Fellowship. I didnt really ask more about it at the time because you dont when you are 10, but in reflecting on Bob Hawkes life recently Mum was telling me that this youth fellowship would go on camps to Point Peron in Rockingham. Thats in my electorate. It was the old camp that many of my friends will remember from when they joined in the Uni Camp For Kids holiday camps for disadvantaged children. It was the old camp. Its gone now, thanks to the asbestos it was built with. The youth fellowship, which included Bob Hawke and the great Western Australian that he married, Hazel Masterson, my mum and her eldest friend, Ivy Heptinstall, and many others, would go on long walks from the Point Peron camp all the way around the coast along the beaches of Shoalwater Bay and then back again to the camp to enjoy that fellowship that formed part of growing up in Western Australia for young people in the late 1940s and early 1950s. Anyone who walks along the beaches of Shoalwater Bay cannot help but be struck by the beauty of these shores and look out at Bird Island, Seal Island and Penguin Island as they break up the horizon that stretches across the vast Indian Ocean. I sometimes think of the people who have walked across the sands of the place I call home, and its oddly reassuring to know that Bob Hawke was one of the many people who have enjoyed Shoalwater Bay and that he did so as part of a fellowship that included my mum, who herself returned to live across from those islands some 10 years later. Its a place we still call home.After school, Bob went to the University of Western Australia to study arts and law, a path many Western Australians, including me and my husband, Jamie King, whos also here, have followed. Bob himself has said his approach to his studies was haphazard—again, a path that many follow at university, until the realisation dawns that its perhaps better to get your act together and get on with the job at hand.

content: An honourable member interjecting—

name: MemberContinuation
content: Ms MADELEINE KING: Maybe it takes five years; maybe it takes less. In recent weeks there has been a great deal of reflection on the motorcycle accident that nearly claimed his life. Bob himself has said it was the seminal turning point of his life. That turning point happened in Kings Park on Mount Eliza, which overlooks Perth. That accident perhaps says something about the challenges of negotiating a motorbike on the winding roads of Kings Park. But, more likely, the accident was a reflection of the recklessness of youth that feels it is invincible. Well, like all of us, Bob Hawke was not invincible, and he learned that in WA. After that accident, he went on to thrive in his studies at the University of Western Australia.Earlier today, the Attorney-General reflected on the great beauty of the UWA campus at Crawley. On this matter, he is right, and we are firmly agreed. Its gardens are unrivalled. So, while being Prime Minister of Australia may be the greatest job in the world, the other contender for this title is to be a gardener at the University of Western Australia. And, of course—wouldnt you know it?—Bob Hawke has done both, as he tended to that campus and all those gardens in his student years.In 1950, Bob Hawke was elected president of the UWA Societies Council. The following year he became guild vice-president, and in 1952 he became the 39th president of the Guild of Undergraduates of the University of Western Australia. In interview, he has reflected: Some of the happiest days of my life were here at the guild and UWA. I have that in common with our Prime Minister, as do many Western Australians. It was an honour to be part of the ceremony in 2013 where the guild honoured him with life membership.Bob established the first international club at the university. He had met students from other countries who had come to study at UWA in Perth as part of the Colombo Plan and he immediately realised the value that could come from creating a greater and more engaging interaction with international students on the campus at that time. He knew instinctively the value of personal relationships and thought it would be a terrible waste—a wasted opportunity for the people of Perth—if local Perth students did not learn from these very intelligent young people from abroad. He was a true internationalist. In this manner and in many others in the future, he made Australia more open.Across 2012 and 2013, I was director of the centenary celebrations for UWA and had the chance to work with Bob a number of times. He was a most willing supporter of this celebration of the university that he recognised as having changed his life and that of many others, as it was the first free university of the British Empire and, therefore, Australia. It offered an opportunity to study for all who had the intellect and the will, so at that time there was a more diverse student body at the university than at universities on the east coast, where payment was a requirement for entry. Bob once came along during the centenary year to a photo shoot outside the old Senate room and at the home of the university cricket club, of which hed been a member and a player. Alongside James Oval, he willingly held the bat and ball while we took some photos for our promotional materials. But he was willing only so long as his car could leave in time to get him to the WACA for the start of the first day of the Perth test.I last spoke with Bob Hawke just over a year ago as I escorted him into Government House on St Georges Terrace to witness the swearing in of our mutual friend and his cabinet colleague, Kim Beazley, as Governor of Western Australia. He was, of course, more frail than before, but he still held court—in Kim Beazleys court, as it happens—with a glass of red wine, chatting to the great and good of Western Australia who wanted to catch their last glimpse and conversation with one of their very best.Im increasingly of the view there is unlikely to be another Prime Minister representing a Western Australian seat. I really hope I am wrong, but that had previously last happened in 1945 and politics has changed as our constituencies and the media demand MPs not stray far from their electorates. Our WA electorates are all very far away from the centre of power in this country, and you cant change that geography. But Western Australians can be very proud to have contributed to this great nation our two greatest prime ministers, John Curtin and Bob Hawke. Western Australians should be proud to know that Bobs life and education in Western Australia formed the greatest peacetime Prime Minister of this nation, the Hon. Robert James Lee Hawke.I offer my sincere condolences, and that of the people of Brand, to his entire family. Thank you for sharing him with us for so long. Your sacrifice has been great and must always be remembered. Vale, Bob Hawke, a truly great Australian—in solidarity forever.
