name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
content: Unsurprisingly, my interest in politics started at a pretty early age. Before serving both the Hawke and Keating governments, my father served in local government first as an alderman—as they were known in those days—and then as a mayor, so politics was a topic of conversation around my household from a young age. Of course, it nurtured an interest in me, but that interest was turbocharged with the election of the Hawke government in 1983. Like all Australians at a young age, I was fully aware of Bob Hawke and the things hed achieved and the trade union movement at that time, and some of his larrikin behaviour as well. But it was something about his arrival in the Lodge that started me thinking more deeply about Australian politics and thinking about the opportunity to serve. He was a real inspiration to me.Bob was, of course, one of a kind—both larrikin and intellectual, champion sculler of beer and Rhodes Scholar. He was a person as comfortable in the parliament, or in a company boardroom or talking to world leaders as he was on the golf course or in the pub. He was quintessentially a man of the people. He was one of us.I remember being so excited when he visited my hometown of Cessnock. Im not sure of the year, but I suspect it was around 1985. Somehow, I dont know why, I got to be the person who delivered his speaking notes for a civic reception he was about to deliver at the Cessnock Town Hall. Theyd obviously arrived behind him and someone, for some reason, had handed them to me to deliver to him. I was very excited by that prospect. I was just amazed at the way he, in a cursory way, seemed to just absorb everything the notes told him. I watched him then put them aside to see to the town hall and, without the notes, use everything that had been contained within them without having to refer to them.I also vividly recall one year when my father took a turn and spent a couple of days in the local hospital. Bob rang the hospital to check on my fathers welfare. That phone call was the talk of the town. The then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, had phoned my father in hospital. Bobs celebrity status was well established by then. It was a celebrity status that not only flowed from his charisma and what hed achieved in public life, but, of course, was influenced by what he had already achieved as a Prime Minister in a pretty short time. Maybe his greatest achievement was when The Australian newspaper front page in 1984 boasted, Hawke is the man who is bringing us together. Its not often a Labor Prime Minister gets such praise from a News Limited newspaper, I would suggest to you.He strived for consensus and unity of purpose. It was a leadership and management style he brought to the 1984 economic summit. He brought it to the cabinet process and, of course, he brought it to interactions between Indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. But it would be a mistake to say consensus was the only part of his model. Theres a bit of mythology running around Australian politics and I must say, without breaking the spirit of these contributions, that we have seen a little bit of it today. Some will have you believe that all the difficult reforms of that period that Bob Hawke led were achieved on a bipartisan basis in this place, whereas, we know nothing could be further from the case. In fact, Bob Hawkes political opponents of the day fought those reforms every step of the way.So Bob always strived for consensus, but when consensus wasnt possible he had the courage and the conviction to forge ahead with those reforms—capital gains tax, asset test for pensioners, PBS reform. They were all difficult reforms, but a person like Bob Hawke was able to progress them, despite opposition from those who sat opposite at the time, because of that strength of leadership.We have lost a great Australian. The Labor Party has lost one of its very, very best. I didnt know Bob all that well when he was Prime Minister, but I had the great privilege of getting to know him very well over the course of the last 10 years at Labor Party events, on the golf course and on a couple of occasions in his Sydney office, where I once went to have him speak to the camera for a video I was doing for Labors country caucus. I gave him a one-minute brief on what I needed him to say, and thats all he needed. In one take, without hesitation, he gave me exactly what I needed. It was only two years ago; he was an elderly gentleman then. Post politics he maintained his dignity and he continued to serve his country but in different ways. It was a life well lived and long lived. We will miss him. My sympathies and condolences go to Blanche and the Hawke family.

name: Mitchell, Rob, MP
content: Robert James Lee Hawke—never before have we had a Prime Minister who was so widely revered by a nation, nor will we again. He was loved not only for his intelligence and leadership. He was loved by all because he was one of us.Much has been said about his amazing life and career. There have been some wonderful personal anecdotes of Bob, and I think thats what Ill concentrate on. Bob was the first PM I can recall actively listening to, especially after the Americas Cup win. Its fair to say that, for me as a young lad, politics was not really on my radar; but when Hawkie spoke you listened. His words, his delivery, his passion told you that things would be better while he was in charge. Hawke gave us a sense of pride and purpose. As history shows, he gave us the ability to stand on our own two feet. Modern Australia is the result of Bob Hawke. Whether it be kings, queens, leaders or people in the street—no matter who you were—Bob spoke your language and listened to your views. He knew that for us to grow there would be tough calls, and he didnt shirk them. He knew that to get through you had to bring the community with you. As he said in 1983:… the first pledge I now make, a commitment which embraces every other undertaking, is that everything we do as a Government will have the one great goal—to reunite this great community of ours, to bring out the best we are truly capable of, together, as a nation, and bring Australia together to win our way through the crisis into which the policies of the past and the men of the past have plunged our country.Those words have stood the test of time.My first meeting with Bob was on a night we were celebrating another great Australian, Peter Cleland. Peters illness had taken a toll, but we were determined to celebrate Peter. When I asked Bobs office if he would come, there was no hesitation. So in my first campaign I was given the honour of sitting with Bob; Peter; Peters wife, Jan; Kim Beazley; and Rob Hulls. I was studying Bob to see how he prepared for his address. There wasnt a lot to learn, because with just a couple of scraps of paper Bob was off. That night was one of the most inspiring and passionate speeches I have ever heard. Over 300 people sat in silence as Bob delivered a powerful message spelling out why Australians needed to remove a conservative government and reminding us that the big reforms, the huge nation-building decisions and putting Australia on the international stage, were all achievements of Labor, and as Labor people we had the responsibility to stand up and to fight for ordinary Australians and our most vulnerable. Bob spoke of his work and passion: tirelessly fighting to give Australians a good living wage. He put a question to the room: how could anyone in good conscience ever vote for the conservatives, who at every single opportunity fought against every single wage increase for working Australians? Those words have stuck fast in my mind. Of course, there was the obligatory singing of Solidarity Forever with Bob at the microphone and his sheepish back-up singers in Kim Beazley, Brian Harding and me. I can let you in on a secret: Bob had the verses to himself, because I didnt know them anyway.In 2010 I had the pleasure of having the great man come to Gisborne. We were in a fight to win the seat, and Bob was there to help us. He let me know that that was how we were going to win it. This was just after the miniseries was put out, and Bob was relishing it. He walked the streets, he entered the shops and he stopped passers-by. If I got more than two inches from him, a stern hand would go around my back and drag me closer. Hed say to the person in front: Are you going to vote for this bloke? Rob is the man you need. In a quiet moment, he leaned over and he said: Stand uncomfortably close, son. That way youll be in the pictures.People flocked from all over to see the great man. The newsagencies sold out the Hawke book in two minutes flat. Bob kindly reminded them that he had made them have a great day. As he passed through the supermarket, I remember a lady who said, Jeez, you were cheeky back then. With a big smile and twist of his head, he said: Still am, love. I still am. He said it in a way that only Bob could. From start to finish, every person took the opportunity to meet with him. Such was his gravitas.To everyone, he was one of them. As a Labor person, Im proud he was one of us. To his family, thank you. Thank you for sharing him. To his friends, cherish the memories. May you rest forever in peace, Bob. Youve earned it.

name: Neumann, Shayne, MP
content: Im grateful for the opportunity to share a few reflections on the Hon. Robert James Lee Hawke, AC. In preparing for this, I consulted with someone who I consider a friend, a mentor and an inspiration. That was the former member for Oxley, Bill Hayden, who is a great Labor Prime Minister that we never had. I consulted him about arguably Labors greatest Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. Bill Hayden maintained enormous respect for Bob Hawke, and they had an excellent working relationship in government together. I thought I would relate some of Bills eloquent condolence message to Bobs family at the time of the state funeral. I quote these words with Bills permission:Much of the country is in mourning at the passing of our former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke.Bob Hawke was a contemporary icon of Labor. I was his foreign minister for just on five years.He was a great manager to work with and I believe that we worked well together as a team.In the period during which I worked with him, to use a cricketing analogy which he would have liked, he was the Don Bradman of Australian politics.There was no peer. He had his weaknesses, which were very human, but he made no secret of them, which endeared him to the Australian public.I am truly saddened by his passing.My sympathies goes to his children and widow, Blanche, who has loyally stood beside him in these more recent declining years.I think Bill Haydens words about Bob Hawke sum up pretty much the sentiments of many people and certainly me perfectly.Of course, Bob and Bill had a special, if nuanced and unusual, relationship. Once rivals for leadership, they became firm partners in reform. After Bill served as foreign affairs minister, it was Bob who appointed him as Governor-General. Bill was delighted that Bob introduced Medicare to cement forever his Medibank legacy from the Whitlam era. It was through Bill that Bob had a real connection with my home city of Ipswich, where he was much loved. Bill would ask Bob to come up to Queensland to campaign for Labor and for local candidates in particular. Of course, Bob usually obliged.I was at the Blair campaign meeting on the Thursday night before the election when the news came of Bobs passing. It was certainly a very sad, sombre and solemn tone to the end of the campaign. Growing up under the tyranny of the Bjelke-Petersen regime in Queensland, I had not voted for a successful Labor Party until Bob Hawke led us to victory in 1983. There was a contrast with that night of his passing to when I walked into a polling booth at East Ipswich in 1983 and voted, as an elector in the electorate in Oxley, for my local member, Bill Hayden. I was disappointed for Bill but hopeful and eager for Bob. He didnt let us down.I had the privilege, like many on this side, of meeting Bob many times over the years, including when he visited South East Queensland, in Canberra and in far away places like Arnhem Land at the Garma festival, which was when I was the shadow Indigenous affairs minister. I remember the praise and adulation he received on these occasions. His energy levels would visibly rise when this would happen. I, along with many Australians, have much to thank Prime Minister Bob Hawke for. He transformed our country and improved the lives of everyday Australians, including my family, in countless ways.Every time someone pulls a Medicare card out of their wallets, they should think of and thank Bob Hawke for it. Whether it is reforms to health care, high school completion rates, Indigenous rights, the economy, superannuation, the workplace, our legal system, sex discrimination, environment, immigration, multiculturalism or achievements like the accord, equal pay and affirmative action, he changed our country for the better. He did it with consensus regularly and confrontation when necessary, domestically and internationally. His reforms modernised our country and set us up for the incredible economic success and social progress of the last 30 years as a prosperous, open and inclusive society.At a critical moment in our history, he saw the burning platform; he knew what needed to be done, he could communicate that effectively and was able to take the nation with him. For that, we owe him an immense debt of gratitude. He rightly deserves to be lauded as Labors greatest peacetime Prime Minister. Thanks to his wife, Blanche, and his family for sharing him with us. Thanks to his first wife Hazel as well. I offer my sincere condolences and that of my electorate of Blair to his family. Vale, Bob Hawke, you good and faithful servant of the Labor Party and the labour movement. You fought the good fight, you kept the faith and you ran the race to the end.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN (Blair)

name: Bandt, Adam, MP
content: Im grateful to have this opportunity to make a few short remarks and pay tribute to the life of Bob Hawke.I was, back in 1983, glued to watching the Americas Cup—I was in Western Australia at the time—like everyone else in the country. Seared in the national consciousness is not only the win but perhaps the memorable phrase, Any boss who sacks anyone for not turning up today is a bum. Im not sure what was more exciting to me as an 11-year-old in Perth—hearing a Prime Minister say bum on television or being able to stay up that late to watch the television. In any event, it was something that not only brought him to the political attention of many of us as young people but also seared in our consciousness that here was a figure who was, in many respects, not only larger than life but also very different from many of the people who had come before him to occupy the position of Prime Minister. I want to pay a tribute, especially to those on the Labor side of politics. A bit of time has passed but I know many people will be feeling it very, very deeply.I want to say two brief things now as we reflect on the life of someone who made a very, very big difference to the country. The first is that his ascension to become the Prime Minister in 1983, where he was able to sit there on television and utter those immortal words, was in large part due to the environment and in large part due to a people-powered movement, not just in Tasmania but right around the country, around the Franklin Dam. That movement energised people in defence of one of the most amazing places of nature in our country. It energised people in this country in a way that probably hadnt been seen before.That incredible movement was taking place, obviously, on the eve of an election, and Bob Hawke took a punt on the environment and he took a punt on people. He made a promise from opposition to stop the destruction of some amazing wilderness. It did come at a cost in Tasmania but it helped him to victory and he delivered. It has to be acknowledged that, as far as the environment and those promises that he made are concerned, he delivered in a way that was consistent with what he promised to do and in a way that no-one else had done before. For that, many of us who have come afterwards owe him and his government a debt of gratitude. Indeed, Bob Brown called him—if I paraphrase correctly—the best Prime Minister Australia has had for the environment. Coming from someone like Bob Brown, I think thats an accolade that is very well deserved.As we look back and reflect on that, one of the things thats notable is that one doesnt need to be in government to work with a people-powered movement to make a difference, to bring about a change and then to get into government and deliver it. As we face some very, very significant challenges, not the least which is climate change—an emergency that we havent seen before—we ought to take a leaf out of his book and understand that taking a punt for the benefit of the environment and for the benefit of people, and making some decisions that, yes, might alienate some people but are ultimately for the national good and for the global good, can pay off. It can pay off in electoral terms, it can pay off for the planet and it can pay off for people.The second reflection that I certainly have as we pay tribute to the life of Bob Hawke is that he ushered in a remarkable era of economic and social change in this country. Much of that I disagree with, because it has to be said that it was that era—the 1980s and subsequently the 1990s—that ushered in neoliberalism in Australia. Neoliberalism is a philosophy I disagree with and I think its no coincidence that the rise of different political movements like the Greens happened at around the same time that those policies were being implemented in Australia. But, it cant be denied that with that came a number of changes to what they called the social wage at the time, and we are the beneficiaries of that and all of us in this parliament should be the defenders of that. Nowhere is that more clear and more the case than in health care, for example, and with Medicare, and we ought to pay tribute to that.But the second thing that we ought to learn from that period of reform—again, as we face immense challenges to deal with climate change and the changes and the potential dislocation that thats going to bring to people and to communities, as well as the opportunities that it opens up—is that we ought not lose sight of the fact that we have the opportunity to do another version of that, but perhaps a different version of it: to remind ourselves that, in Australian history, it was possible to get people around a table and to make significant social and economic reforms that ultimately set the country up in a certain way for the future. As I say, I disagreed with some of those reforms, but the fact is they were done and it should be acknowledged that they were done. We have the opportunity, in a sense, to learn from that and to do a mark 2 of that to ensure that we deal with the climate challenge and with some of the challenges of underemployment that we have in this country. That kind of big vision is something that we ought not lightly lose sight of.In conclusion, I know there are many people in Melbourne who probably voted for a member of parliament who became a member of a government under Bob Hawke. There are many people who still hold a lot of affection for him and there are many, many significant things that he achieved. Im pleased to be able to pay tribute to his life.

Speaker: Mr BANDT (Melbourne)

name: Owens, Julie, MP
content: There is much to talk about when it comes to celebrating the life of Bob Hawke. I actually participated in my first campaign in 1983 because of the Franklin. I didnt join the party at the time, but I volunteered in that election. I didnt know Bob Hawke as well as many of the people in this House did, so Im not going to talk about the man; Im going to talk about the changes that he made—in fact, just one change: to education.Im only going to talk about education because the Hawke government changed our expectations. He expanded our world. For people in neighbourhoods like the one where I grew up, and in the heart of Western Sydney, the Hawke government lifted our gaze to the possibilities of education. And we needed to lift our gaze, because, when Labor won government in 1983, Australia had some of the lowest high school completion rates in the Western world. As bad as that was, Western Sydney lagged a long way behind the rest of Sydney. If you meet Western Sydney today, youll see one of the characteristics that I love most: we are a place where families with no history of tertiary education send a child to university for the first time. I was the first in my family, and in Western Sydney Im surrounded by thousands of others who are first in family and proud of it. The then Prime Minister Bob Hawke laid the foundations for that during his term. The Hawke government, by the way, gave us Western Sydney University. Whitlam committed to it, Fraser reneged and the Hawke and Keating government built it.For me, its the opportunity of high school education that touches me most, and perhaps thats because it is personal. I went to school before the Hawke years, in the sixties and seventies, and one of my clearest memories at that time, and one that still disturbs me to this day, was sitting in a classroom and hearing the teacher tell us that one of our friends had special dispensation to leave school at 14 and go to work, because his parents couldnt afford to keep him at school. I remember the look on his face, the slumped shoulders, him looking at the ground with no eye contact. We didnt see him again. He was a smart, attractive, athletic, witty kid who had everything in him to do well but not the things he needed to do something that today we would consider basic: finish high school. We left school in large numbers. We had two senior classes. Out of hundreds that started grade 8, we had two senior classes—one physics class that was half-full and one advanced maths. I was the only girl who studied science and maths, and only one of a handful that went on to tertiary education. The exception was for teaching, which was paid for by a scholarship. The cost of poverty was extremely high. The cost of disadvantage was wasted talent and lost opportunity, both at the individual level and at the national level.In the Hawke government, we saw a commitment to providing opportunity for all and to expecting that children could do something as basic in todays world as finishing high school. I want you to understand how profound the disadvantage was in Western Sydney, so I am going to talk numbers. Ive got a report here that came from the 1987 parliamentary report into retention rates. It breaks up the community into 10 socioeconomic groups, with one as the lowest socioeconomic group and 10 as the highest. What you see with these is that the difference in boys between the lowest socioeconomic group and the highest is 30 per cent—less than half of children. This was in 1987, by the way, after there had been quite a substantial improvement. Forty-three per cent of boys in the lower socioeconomic group finished high school, and over 75 per cent in the highest group did. Thats an extraordinary difference. For girls it was about the same—53 per cent in the lowest group, and 85 in the highest group. Again, a 30 per cent difference between the lowest socioeconomic group and the highest. But its even more extraordinary if you understand that the average, which was about 55 per cent at the time, wasnt in the middle. It was actually so skewed towards the upper socioeconomic areas that 70 per cent of the population was below average in terms of retention. Thirty per cent was in the top three—no, I obviously shouldnt talk numbers this late at night. Either way, the skewing was extraordinary. Seventy per cent of the year 12 population completed year 12 at below-average rates. Again, you look at the numbers and you see that 43 per cent of kids finished school in the lowest socioeconomic group, but it was only 50 per cent in the seventh, then 55, 63, and then 76 per cent in the 10th—extraordinary skewing towards upper socioeconomic groups. In Western Sydney there were some profound challenges.How did they do it? How did they increase the retention rate from around 30 to the mid-70s? Well, with some quite profound change. When the Hawke government came to power, the Commonwealths influence on schooling policy was indirect. It consisted of funding state based programs. The Hawke government knew that if education were to serve the needs of the economy, then education policy must be steered at federal level. So they created the federal Department of Employment, Education and Training, and they also established the Australian Education Council, comprising federal, state and tertiary education ministers. It was in the 1980s that we got a federal department for education. The first national goals for schooling were established in 1989.They did the hard structural changes, but they also put effort in on the ground. Much of change is due to the targeting of areas of most need. The $70 million participation and equity program focused on access and participation, targeting the 40 per cent of schools with the lowest retention rates and focusing on curriculum and school culture. It made an extraordinary difference. Imagine that difference from my time in school, when leaving at 15 was the norm, to a world where staying in school is the usual path.We have a lot to thank the Hawke government for. He changed our lives for the better in so many ways. This is just one of them. Vale Bob Hawke.

Speaker: Ms OWENS (Parramatta)

name: Giles, Andrew, MP
content: Im very pleased to be able to make a very short contribution to this very important motion. All of us here in Australia in 2019 walk in Bob Hawkes shadow—especially those of us who are part of the Labor family and everyone who sees our countrys story as written by its enlargers. Through this prism, none emerge more significant than Bob Hawke. Deputy Speaker and friends on many side of the House, if we believe, as I passionately do, that it was Gough Whitlam who imagined how modern Australia might be, it was Bob Hawke who made it and fixed so much of it so firmly in place that conservatives have not been able to dismantle its achievements. It was under Hawke that we as a country reached out to the world, standing confidently and optimistically in our place. His confidence in Australians, his belief in his fellow Australians and his love for his fellow Australians were turned into a confidence in Australia as a nation.This debate has been going on for some time today, as is appropriate, and I am of the view that certainly the Bob Hawke of the 1970s would feel its way past time that we adjourned to the pub for a more informal set of reflections! So I propose to be very brief and not go over ground that has been covered so eloquently by my colleagues, including our leader, and the Prime Minister and so many speakers on the government side in paying due respect.But I want to touch on four things very quickly and then make a brief personal reflection. When we discuss how Bob Hawke opened Australia to the world, the one thing that we must focus on is how he built the social wage, an absolutely critical compact by a government that was reaching out to the world with a sense of a modern, globalised economy and a sense of responsibility to citizenship. If we think about that cornerstone of the social wage in Medicare, we understand just how important Bob Hawkes legacy is to how Australians see our country and our relationship to one another. The member for Parramatta spoke of school retention. Its amazing to think of Australia before that goal and what it has meant for us as a knowledge based economy. We cant neglect to reflect on his extraordinary contribution to the environment, his recognition of the challenge of climate change as a core responsibility for government to respond to and the series of commitments he made to preserve our beautiful natural environment—from the Franklin all the way to Kakadu and Antarctica.Lastly, I mention his compassion. I think the thing that struck people more than anything else at the beautiful memorial at the Sydney Opera House was the reflection on his determination to do justice to those displaced by the tragic events in Tiananmen Square. That sense of compassion overriding advice in recognition of common humanity is something we should all look to as we recall the Hawke legacy, as indeed we look to how he conducted his government and his approach to politics and how he presented himself to Australians—a very true picture, which I think explains so much of the love for him that existed then and endures today and will endure beyond today.Like probably most of us, I have my images of Bob Hawke that have guided me. There was the 1990 election. His very narrow victory then was the first political contest that energised and affected me. I was very privileged to work with and enjoy the mentorship of a man called Peter Redlich at the firm Holding Redlich. Peter Redlich was a great mate of Bob Hawkes. Peter Redlich couldnt understand why my political journey didnt follow Hawkes to a more pragmatic direction within the party.

name: MemberContinuation
content: Mr GILES: Many cant understand it! But to see close up their friendship, how they modernised Labor and how Bob Hawke modernised Australia was an extraordinary privilege. To have briefly spent time with Bob Hawke is something I will cherish, as I will cherish the fact that Bob Hawke got to spend a little bit of time with my son, Daniel Giles, on the campaign trail in 2010. Im not sure if Daniel remembers this, but I hope—in fact, I know—that hell be talking about it for many years to come. All my condolences go to Blanche and Bobs family and to all of those who loved him. Vale, Bob Hawke.

name: Husic, Ed, MP
content: I want to make some contributions to this condolence motion for former Prime Minister Bob Hawke. In doing so, Im very conscious of the terrific contributions that have been made through the course of the day reflecting on specific elements of Bob Hawkes legacy. I dont seek to replicate all of those. I want to focus on three things in this part of the day: his focus on belief, specifically belief in himself, in our people and in our nation. I think the belief he had in these three groups, particularly himself, obviously, were very important to driving the contribution that he made to our country.A lot of people have reflected on Bob Hawkes self-belief, and weve had a wry smile about that, but the reality is that politics is a difficult vocation. Pushing for change against a lot of interests that will counter your push in very significant ways is not easy. You have to have faith in yourself and what you believe in if youre to change the face of this country. Bear in mind the challenge that he had at that time, in the early eighties. As people have said, the country had been in the grip of drought and recession, had high unemployment and high inflation and had an economy that had reached the end of what it could do in the way that it was structured. To do those things—make those changes and argue those policies—and to put them to the Australian people needed a lot of confidence. Obviously, having that self-belief was very important. But it was not just that. It was being comfortable of himself, within himself, to move with a wide variety of people.People have reflected on his friendship with Sir Peter Abeles. He could talk to that part of the country, to the captains of industry, as they were called, right through to the people on the street. He was able to do that because he was comfortable in himself and did not believe that by virtue of the fact that he was dealing with business, with industry, he was sacrificing who he was. It meant that he had confidence in himself to change as times suited. The Bob Hawke who led the ACTU was different from the Bob Hawke who led the country. He recognised that he had to move with the times. Again, it required a comfort within himself to be able to do so.As much as we are venerating the Hawke-Keating era, many of us grew up in those times and saw what they were able to achieve. There is not a requirement on us to maintain strictly the legacy, to return to the Hawke-Keating legacy of itself. Hawke and Keating were important because they were modernisers. They saw what was happening at that point in time and they made sure government fit those times. This is the most important legacy. It is not to repeat Hawke-Keating but to understand that at the point in time you find yourself on that side of the House you are ready to make those changes. That is an important lesson in itself.He had belief in people. What I found most important about Bob Hawke was that he believed people were there to be convinced. He was not there delivering the lines of the day or what the focus group said needed to be said. He actually thought that, if people had a view and it was different from his, it was his role to convince them to move away from something they held strongly and dearly to themselves for the better outcome of the nation. I remember very well, in all the words that were being said when we all found out that Bob Hawke had passed on, Barrie Cassidy recounted a story about Bob Hawke at a point in time when there was anti-immigration feeling and he had resolutions in this place to contend with. Advisers were saying to him, Bob, you probably shouldnt speak against this, because theres strong sentiment in favour of it. Cassidy recalled, Hawkes response was not to kowtow to that feeling but instead to say, Give me the arguments to convince people otherwise. He had belief in people. He believed that people wanted to be convinced. The greatest respect you can extend to people is to believe inherently in their intelligence, to put forward the arguments for them to consider and then to respond accordingly. This is a very important lesson, and one I think stands true today as much as it did then.His belief in people extended to his expectations of people. People have reflected on the achievements on school retention rates, but he was saying to people, particularly in my part of Western Sydney, I expect that you will continue school, that you will be able to go on to years 11 and 12.I saw it myself in Western Sydney: when youre a year 10 student out in Blacktown, and you have 150 students in year 10 and youre left with 50 in year 11 and everyone leaving the system. Why? It wasnt an end in itself. It was a realisation that the world was changing and that peoples skills needed to be enhanced, and that for the longer term it was better for them, in terms of the things they wanted to achieve in their life, that they stayed in school longer. He had an expectation. It was not, Just because youre from Western Sydney you wont go to school and broaden your mind and get those skills. He expected you to go on at school and he made sure that government was resourcing those schools so that people could achieve. He had a belief in people.Finally, his belief in country. He believed that this nation had a legitimate place on the world stage—not just a place but that its voice should be heard. People have talked about our role in helping drive the establishment of APEC. There are the other things we talked about, like trade liberalisation. For example, he, with others, drove the establishment of the Cairns Group to argue for trade liberalisation at a time when people asked why we would push for trade liberalisation when no-one else would. Mind you, we see a similar sort of argument on climate change: why should Australia make a contribution on climate change when the rest of the world is doing what it does and we cant possibly make a dent there? But the trade liberalisation that he pushed for, and the way it would help the economy and generate new job opportunities and wealth for the nation, was important. He believed in that.But the biggest thing in terms of the world stage, where he believed that Australia could legitimately have a voice, was his belief that a country which separated its people on the basis of race was not a legitimate form of government and that we should press for better within the Commonwealth. He said that we should take this on. As a trade union official or a Prime Minister of this nation, what he did—and can I just say, for those of us who think that Australia, with its weight and size, cant necessarily influence the direction or the way that things happen around the globe, we should remember we can do this. People like Bob Hawke and others showed that where it is right to do so we should have a belief in our nation and we should push for better on the world stage. We should not take it as a given or just believe that we should retreat and not push for better on the world stage. Amongst all the things that Bob Hawke did, ending apartheid, for what it was worth, is one of his biggest legacies, because it reflected everything about Bob Hawke—a belief in himself, a belief that people deserve better and the belief that a country can actually make a meaningful difference. We cannot thank him enough for what he did for this nation.He helped me out on my campaign. Time prohibits me from speaking more about the profound impact that he had on me as a person, but all of us in our contributions today simply cannot say enough thank yous for what he did. We cannot extend enough our condolences to his family for what they are going through. This nation is better because of a person who had belief in himself and the country he ultimately went on to lead. Vale Bob Hawke, and thank you for everything youve done.

name: Keogh, Matt, MP
content: I remember the first time that I met Bob Hawke. I was but a lad riding on my dads shoulders. It was at Frye Park in Kelmscott, and there was a huge crowd. Thats really all I can remember, but I was only about three or four at the time. Im told by our local state MP from that time that the occasion was the opening of the new Kelmscott soccer club facilities just up from where my office is now. He said it was like the coming of the Messiah—thousands of people all jostling just to be able to touch Bob on the head as he walked through the crowd. In a way, that is how I have and will forever remember Bob Hawke: the man adored by the people. Such occasions were common. A former federal MP for my community described it as like watching Pope Bob. Another predecessor of mine noted the delight Bob had at posing for a photo at the gravestone of an Australian soldier, killed in action during the war in France, with the same name as that MP.A pseudo Western Australian, Bob Hawke attended school in WA and studied law at the University of Western Australia with my grandfather in the late 1940s. They were both born in South Australia too. Prime Minister Hawke led the federal Labor government I grew up under and he epitomised the Labor values that I learnt. In a way, they encapsulated that government. In a sense, it was the third way before that was a thing. As our 23rd Prime Minister, he reformed our country in many ways with one of the most brave and ambitious policy agendas in our history. Indeed, in modernising our country he changed our country and transformed our economy. He turned Australia into a world leader in so many areas. Critically, though, it was full of hope and bold of idea. However, as much as the government benches now try to claim credit and align themselves with the policies from that time, there has always been a critical difference, and that is in the way that Labor, under Hawke, always ensured a proper social safety net, for growth is stronger when it is shared, and when wages and living standards rise everyone in the community should benefit.Bob was also a strong advocate for womens rights, striving to achieve equal payment for men and women and protecting women from sexual harassment in the workplace. The current Workplace Gender Equality Act 2012 is the legacy of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act of 1986. By 1990, the Hawke Labor government had committed more than $1 million to establish the Commonwealth-state National Committee on Violence Against Women.When Bob came to office, fewer than three in 10 kids finished school. By the time he left, that number was eight in 10. Bob helped us realise a persons education or future prospects should not be determined by their postcode, and this is a message that continues to resonate with me today. Prime Minister Hawke also infamously said that by 1990 no Australian child would be living in poverty. I remember studying cartoons about this in my social studies classes in high school in the mid-1990s. I recall thinking at the time that it was a bold goal that clearly wasnt achieved, but in no way was it something that should not be striven for. He inspired me to work to help change the story for the kids in my community, one of Western Australias lowest socioeconomic areas. Bobs beginnings were in union organising and bargaining for all, making sure, in a way that was responsible, through the Prices and Incomes Accord, for economic growth, that every worker received a fair days pay for a fair days work.Perhaps most quintessentially, each and every Australian carries with them each and every day a monument to Bob Hawke and his government—a green and gold reminder in the form of a Medicare card. It ensures that we do, indeed, live in the lucky country and that the health of one of us matters to all of us.I turn now to my new shadow portfolio of WA resources. Theres a good chance that our resources industry wouldnt be what it is today without Bob Hawkes input. He was a pivotal figure in opening up the Pilbara iron ore industry to foreign investment. In the late 1980s, he was one of the main drivers behind ensuring delivery of the landmark Channar joint venture agreement, a 20-year joint venture that has resulted in the export of more than 250 million tonnes of iron ore to China by Rio Tinto. Today, China accounts for more than 83 per cent of WAs iron ore exports. Bob is also credited with facilitating the petroleum resource rent tax, alongside WA senator Peter Walsh and, of course, Treasurer Paul Keating. This was a vital initiative on tax reform for minerals, which effectively saved Western Australia from the possibility of going broke at the beginning of the term of the Hawke government.Now, no event that Bob took part in lately was complete without a bellowing rendition of Solidarity Forever. Ill spare the chamber my version. On one of his most recent trips to WA, when he came to help in the election of the McGowan state Labor government, it was no different. On that visit I had the opportunity to introduce my son, Nicholas, to Bob, and later Bob sang Solidarity Forever with us all. Soon enough Nicholas will be old enough to appreciate what a special moment that was for him and for me.I extend my condolences to Blanche, Bobs children and his grandchildren. Vale, Hawkie. Rest in peace.Debate adjourned.
